summary: Paul Merson reignited his criticism of Andros Townsend after Townsend was substituted on late in Tottenham’s 0-0 draw with Burnley, joking on Twitter about his limited playing time. Previously, Merson questioned Townsend’s inclusion in the England squad, but after Townsend scored an equaliser for England against Italy, Merson admitted he was wrong. Townsend responded to Merson’s earlier criticism on Twitter. Despite appearing to have settled their differences, Merson took another jab at Townsend following the Burnley match.

Chelsea have made a formal offer for FC Tokyo’s 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, confirmed by FC Tokyo’s president Naoki Ogane. If Muto joins Chelsea, he would spend next season on loan at their Dutch partner club, Vitesse Arnhem. Muto has played for FC Tokyo since 2013, has 37 club appearances with 16 goals, and 11 caps for Japan with 1 goal. He recently graduated from Keio University with an economics degree. The offer is not linked to Chelsea’s new £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber. Muto is honored by the offer, though undecided about joining. The potential deal is worth about £4 million. Chelsea may tour Japan this summer as part of their partnership with Yokohama Rubber.

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers, especially boys. The study of over 12,000 two-year-olds showed a higher risk of obesity in those with early or repeated antibiotic exposure, though it did not prove causation. Researchers suggest antibiotics may disrupt gut bacteria in ways that promote weight gain. The study highlights concern over increasing childhood obesity rates, particularly in boys, and calls for more careful use of antibiotics in infants due to possible links to obesity and other negative health effects. Overuse of antibiotics is also linked to increased antibiotic resistance.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony in front of hundreds of tourists, as captured on a tourist’s video. The guard dropped his rifle, quickly got up, and appeared embarrassed as people looked on. The incident is believed to have been caused by metal protectors on the soles of his boots. The Changing of the Guard is a major tourist attraction, featuring fully operational soldiers, not just ceremonial ones. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

A remake of the landmark 1977 miniseries "Roots"—about African slave Kunta Kinte and his descendants—is being produced by A&E networks to air in 2016 across A&E, Lifetime, and History. LeVar Burton, the original Kinte, will co-executive produce. The new adaptation will be more contemporary, draw further from Alex Haley’s original novel, and involve historical scholars for authenticity. Producers aim to introduce this important story to new generations, acknowledging changes in society and ongoing racial issues.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, claims he was sexually assaulted and forced into an orgy by Clarence House staff on his first day in 1978, when the Queen Mother lived there. He reported being pinned, groped, and threatened, and left the job immediately. His complaints were initially ignored by palace officials until last year, when they were finally passed to police amid wider abuse investigations. A retired aide has denied involvement. Police are currently investigating, and the Palace says it will cooperate fully.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced they are expecting a child in a rap video set to the theme song of the '90s sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, which shows them rapping in a car and sharing a sonogram at the end, has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube. They made the video to inform distant family and friends of the news. The couple expressed surprise at the video's popularity and mentioned the possibility of making another video after learning the baby's gender. Jesse is noted as the great-great-grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek. Previously, Melissa had recorded Jesse's reaction to the pregnancy using a message on their dog. The passage also notes a similar pregnancy announcement video made by another couple in Pennsylvania.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film *Gone With the Wind* was auctioned for $137,000 by Heritage Auctions in Beverly Hills. This faded gray jacket and skirt ensemble, originally slate blue-gray, was worn in several key scenes and was part of over 150 items from the film sold from James Tumblin's collection. Tumblin, who started collecting film memorabilia in the 1960s and amassed over 300,000 items, bought the dress for $20 after rescuing it from being discarded. Other notable auction items included a straw hat worn by Leigh ($52,500), Rhett Butler’s suit ($55,000), and a black bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia de Havilland ($30,000). The film, celebrating its 75th anniversary last year, was based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 novel, and actress Hattie McDaniel became the first African-American to win an Academy Award for her role as Mammy.

A two-year-old boy fell 10 to 12 feet into the cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the railing. The incident occurred while the mother was holding the boy and another child. The boy was rescued by his parents before emergency responders arrived, suffering only minor injuries and was listed in stable condition at the hospital. The cheetahs did not approach the child or his parents. Eyewitness accounts suggest the child was dangled over the edge, and as a result, the zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family. The exhibit was closed after the incident.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, has been mysteriously turned to face a house instead of the road, though it has not worked for over two years since fixed cameras across the West Midlands were decommissioned in 2013 due to outdated technology. Speed enforcement is now managed by mobile units, motorway cameras, and traffic officers. Birmingham City Council is aware of the situation and may remove the camera, but the site is not included in plans to reintroduce cameras using updated digital technology. The house owners have not commented.

Usain Bolt will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2-3, as announced by the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association. Bolt, who is healthy and ready to run, expressed excitement about joining the team and emphasized Jamaica's strong relay tradition. The full Jamaican team roster will be announced later.

Neymar and Dani Alves showed support for Barcelona by attending a Euro League basketball El Clasico match with Neymar’s sister Rafaella, where Barcelona narrowly defeated Real Madrid 85-80. Despite the win, Real Madrid remains top of their Euro League division by points difference. Recently, Neymar led Brazil to a 1-0 victory over Chile and endured harsh challenges during the match. Before the international break, Barcelona won the football El Clasico and now lead La Liga by four points, aiming for a treble as they prepare to face Celta Vigo.

Italy is dealing with increasing numbers of migrants from Africa and the Middle East trying to reach Europe, with 8,480 rescued between Friday and Monday. There are unconfirmed reports from survivors that a boat carrying 550 migrants capsized, leaving 400 missing; however, the Italian coast guard has yet to find evidence of this. In 2015, over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy in the first three months, mainly from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, often using Libya as a transit point. At least 480 migrants have died this year due to dangerous conditions at sea, such as bad weather, overcrowded boats, and abandonment by crews.

Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal over other interested clubs, including Liverpool, after leaving Barcelona, though only Sanchez knows his exact reasons. Manager Arsene Wenger is pleased with Sanchez’s decision and his instant impact, as the Chilean forward has already scored 19 goals this season. Wenger acknowledged Liverpool’s interest and suggested it could have been linked to negotiations over Luis Suarez’s move to Barcelona. He praised Sanchez’s qualities and quick adaptation to English football. Wenger also downplayed speculation about a possible transfer for Liverpool’s Raheem Sterling and complimented Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers for adapting well after selling Suarez and coping with injuries.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling’s hour record on June 7 at London’s Olympic Velodrome. The current record, set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February, stands at 52.491km. Wiggins, who recently ended his Team Sky career, aims to set a lasting mark in front of a capacity 6,000 crowd, with tickets on sale from April 19. His attempt follows changes in UCI regulations that have renewed interest in the hour record, and other riders such as Briton Alex Dowsett are also planning attempts. Wiggins sees the record as a major challenge and part of his preparation for the 2016 Rio Olympics.

Serena Williams struggled but eventually defeated Sara Errani in a tough three-set Fed Cup singles match, though she and Alison Riske later lost the doubles, leading to the US team’s relegation to World Group II. Williams admitted the match was an “eye-opener,” revealing she was not fully prepared for the claycourt season. Despite her singles win, the US lost the overall tie, and captain Mary Joe Fernandez emphasized the need for harder work to return to the elite group next year.

River Plate are interested in re-signing Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao, who previously played for them before moving to Porto in 2009. River Plate vice president Matias Patanian expressed that the club "dream of Falcao" returning, though a deal is complicated. Falcao has struggled at Manchester United during his loan spell, scoring only four Premier League goals, and it is uncertain if United will keep him or if he will return to Monaco. Recently, Falcao equaled Colombia’s all-time goalscoring record. He originally joined River Plate at age 15 and scored 34 goals in 90 appearances for them.

Ella Henderson, a finalist from 2012’s The X Factor, has been announced as the official face of Batiste’s 2015 ‘Ready For It’ dry shampoo campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign, created by the MILES agency, features Ella in various hairstyles and outfits and includes a TV advert with her single "Mirror Man." Ella expressed her excitement about working with a brand she uses, while her management described this partnership as a natural fit for both the artist and Batiste.

A billboard in Kenosha, Wisconsin, featuring officer Pablo Torres—who fatally shot Aaron Siler on March 14—is causing shock and distress to Siler’s family and friends, who find it disrespectful and are asking for its removal. The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, was intended to thank the community for its support, not to offend. Siler, who was wanted on felony warrants, was killed after a police chase in which he allegedly armed himself. Torres is on leave pending investigation. This incident followed another shooting involving Torres, which was found justified. The investigation into Siler’s death is ongoing.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Pakistan border, according to Iranian state media. Three militants, allegedly from the group Jaish al Adal, were also killed. The militants reportedly crossed from Pakistan into Iran for the attack and later fled back across the border. Iran has criticized Pakistan for not controlling such militants and has asked Pakistan to apprehend the surviving assailants. Jaish al Adal, a Sunni group opposed to Iranian influence, has claimed responsibility and has carried out similar attacks in the past. The Pakistani government condemned the incident, is investigating, and said it will act if militants are found in Pakistan.

The passage discusses a recent political exchange in Japan where former wrestler-turned-lawmaker Antonio Inoki asked Defense Minister Gen Nakatani if Japan's Air Self Defense Force had ever encountered UFOs from outer space. Nakatani responded that while fighter jets are scrambled for unidentified flying objects that could violate Japan's airspace, there have been no encounters with extraterrestrial UFOs—only birds or earthly flying objects. The passage also provides background on Inoki’s colorful career in wrestling, politics, and public life, noting his various exploits and personality traits. The topic of alien visitors has come up before in Japanese politics, with past ministers also contemplating the issue.

A passenger at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport was hospitalised with deep cuts after standing on a toilet rim—which broke and caused him to fall. He was avoiding sitting due to cleanliness concerns. The man required numerous stitches and initially admitted to his friends that he was squatting, but told police he had been sitting, possibly to avoid compensation liabilities. Authorities called the incident an accident and reminded travelers toilets are for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, 56, from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for allegedly molesting a girl from age 9 to 13 and secretly filming her and others in a bathroom over several years using a hidden camera. Police traced the camera to Rebbie after the now-15-year-old girl discovered it. Investigators found 41 videos, including footage of victims showering, which Rebbie admitted to making and viewing. He faces multiple charges, including aggravated indecent assault, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. Rebbie is being held on $500,000 bail and his preliminary hearing is set for May 1. The nature of his relationship with the victim’s family is unknown.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama's latest series features portraits of daughters posing calmly next to their fathers, who leap energetically into the air wearing suits, in front of Japanese landmarks. The images, part of his book "Daughter and Salary Man," aim to show fathers expressing a fun, heroic side, contrasting their usual seriousness. The unusual and playful photos have attracted significant online interest.

Paul Downton was dismissed as England's managing director, shifting attention to the start of the county championship season and speculation about Kevin Pietersen's possible return to the England team. Pietersen appeared thoughtful yet jovial during Surrey's team photo at the KIA Oval as he prepared for the new season, aiming to impress and regain a spot in the national side. His return seems more likely following Downton’s sacking, which had previously led to Pietersen's exclusion after England's poor Ashes performance. Surrey is set to begin their campaign at Glamorgan on April 19, with an upcoming match against Oxford MCCU.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian football club facing relegation, have sacked coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani. Ze Maria, a former Brazil international defender, was initially fired, then reinstated, but has now been replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic. Ceahlaul are 16th in the standings, six points from safety, and Ze Maria was their third coach this season.

Radamel Falcao moved from Monaco to Manchester United on a season-long loan but has struggled to regain his form after a serious knee injury, scoring only four goals. United are unlikely to make his transfer permanent due to his poor performance. Nabil Dirar, Falcao’s former Monaco teammate, believes Falcao regrets leaving Monaco, where he was unhappy but would have played regularly and participated in the Champions League.

A very tall man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt robbed a Christchurch dairy on Saturday, stealing the till and about $1,500 in cash. He demanded money from the owner's daughter before fleeing. No weapons were used, and police continue to search for the suspect, appealing to the public for information.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice for having inappropriate sexual relationships with two 15-year-old students. She was first arrested on March 19 after admitting to kissing and allowing one student to touch her breasts. She was released on bail and put on administrative leave. Days later, a second student accused her of having sex with him on two consecutive nights in January, leading to her second arrest. Granado has since been released on $50,000 bail. The school district took immediate action by suspending her, and further details about her plea are unknown.

A video viewed over 500,000 times shows a crocodile in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, swimming through a marina with a dead pet dog belonging to a local bike shop owner in its jaws. New Zealander Tim Weston, who witnessed the event while on holiday, described the crocodile holding onto the dog for hours as crowds watched in shock. The area, built among mangroves, is known for frequent crocodile sightings due to their nearby sanctuary and increasing proximity to humans caused by urbanisation. The video has prompted horrified reactions on social media.

Steve Bruce remains confident Hull City can avoid relegation from the Premier League, despite a 2-0 defeat to Southampton leaving them just two points above the drop zone with six games remaining against tough opponents. Bruce had hoped 10 wins would secure safety, but Hull has only six so far and he now believes eight or nine may suffice. He attributes Hull’s struggles mainly to long-term injuries to key players. Meanwhile, Southampton moved up to fifth after the win, but their manager Ronald Koeman faced issues over penalty-taking responsibilities within his squad.

A teacher, Ian Guffick, was banned from teaching after allowing and personally altering pupils’ SATs exam answers at Mitton Manor Primary School in Gloucestershire. This misconduct occurred after the exam session had ended and led to the annulment of all SATs results for the school. An investigation by the local education authority confirmed that answers had been changed outside exam conditions. Guffick admitted his actions, described as unacceptable professional conduct, and was banned from the classroom for at least two years. He expressed remorse, and was given 28 days to appeal the decision.

Anders Lindegaard, a Danish goalkeeper at Manchester United, has struggled for playing time since joining from Aalesunds in 2010, making only 19 league appearances in five seasons and currently being third-choice at the club. Off the pitch, he married Swedish model Misse Beqiri, who has Albanian roots, in a beach wedding in Mauritius last year; the couple has been together since 2012 and have a son. Beqiri is popular on Instagram, frequently sharing modelling photos. Despite Lindegaard's limited football success, his personal life is going well.

The iconic blue letters that once sat atop Yankee Stadium in the Bronx failed to sell at a Sotheby’s auction, despite being valued at $300,000 to $600,000. The only bid, for $260,000, came from a Sotheby’s employee trying to prompt interest. The letters, owned by Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson since 2008, had been on the stadium since 1976. Jackson hoped a new generation would enjoy them. In contrast, a New York Mets bullpen car, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500 at the same auction.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers spoke to Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional responsibilities after Sterling was seen inhaling nitrous oxide and both were pictured with shisha pipes. Rodgers decided not to discipline either player and wants to move on from the incident. He emphasized the challenges young players face under scrutiny and reminded them of their responsibilities as professionals. Rodgers also has Steven Gerrard available for the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa following a suspension but did not say if Gerrard would start. Rodgers’ main focus is leading Liverpool to their first FA Cup final under his management.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal’s midfielder, returned to London after helping Germany beat Georgia 2-0 in a Euro 2016 qualifier and posted a photo relaxing with his dog. Having missed Arsenal’s previous match due to illness, Ozil is expected to play against Liverpool next. Despite rumors of him being in a nightclub, manager Arsene Wenger denied them. Ozil has contributed four assists and three goals since returning from injury and says he is now well-adjusted to English football, enjoying the regular matches and fitting in perfectly at Arsenal.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu stated the club is very happy with manager Luis Enrique, denying any plans to replace him despite speculation. Enrique, who joined last summer on a two-year contract, has impressed in his role, with Barcelona close to winning the La Liga title and still in contention for three trophies. Bartomeu highlighted Enrique’s hard work and recent victory over Valencia, where Suarez and Messi scored. The club will consider Enrique’s contract in the future.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to sign a new long-term contract with Liverpool, expected to be worth around £100,000 a week and running until 2020. As club vice-captain and a key midfielder with 13 assists and seven goals this season, Henderson may become club captain when Steven Gerrard leaves. He is the third major player after Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho to extend his contract under Brendan Rodgers. Talks with Raheem Sterling on a new deal will resume at the end of the season.

Filipe Luis wants to stay at Chelsea until his contract ends, despite interest from Atletico Madrid in re-signing him. Although he has struggled for a regular starting position, Luis insists he is happy at Chelsea. He recently played for Brazil during the international break, but is now focused on Chelsea’s Premier League title run-in. Manager Jose Mourinho is urging the team to stay focused and win each remaining game, as the team faces nine challenging matches ahead.

Nathan Hughes, a Wasps rugby player, initially received a three-match ban and red card for a collision where his knee accidentally struck George North’s head, knocking North unconscious during a match on March 27. Despite the original ruling of recklessness, many—including players and officials—criticized the ban, emphasizing the lack of intent. Wasps appealed the suspension, and the appeal panel rescinded both Hughes’s red card and ban after considering new evidence, deciding no foul play had occurred. As a result, Hughes is now eligible to return, though he is not expected to play until April 26. North suffered his third head injury in two months and has been advised to rest for at least a month.

A series of dramatic red sunsets seen in Washington and nearby areas were caused by smoke from wildfires in southeastern Siberia, which were started by farmers and spread out of control due to strong winds. The smoke traveled across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, creating intense red skies by filtering out shorter wavelength colors in sunlight. These effects will diminish as the smoke disperses and air quality improves.

Becky Schoenig, a mother from St. Louis, Missouri, had her new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen just over a month after purchasing it. Police recovered the car after a tip from a man named Mick Sexton, but it had been altered with red rims, red detailing, and orange accents. Rather than get upset, Schoenig humorously thanked the thieves on Facebook for "pimping out" her car, though she noted it needed professional cleaning due to the smell of cigarettes and marijuana. To honor Sexton, she created a smoothie called the "Sexton on Wheels" at her restaurant. Friends describe Schoenig as vibrant and someone who enjoys making others laugh.

Manchester City players stand to lose £500,000 each in bonuses if the team fails to qualify for the Champions League this season. Their contracts are incentivised to help the club meet financial fair play rules, with about £12 million in total bonuses at stake. After losing to Manchester United, City's chances of qualifying are uncertain, as they are in fourth place and only four points ahead of Liverpool, who have a game in hand. Only the top three Premier League teams automatically qualify for the Champions League; the fourth-place team must win a qualifying round. Manager Manuel Pellegrini admitted the team’s poor recent form, with seven losses and early exits from other competitions, and acknowledged the challenge in signing top players if they miss Champions League qualification.

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated Manchester City 1-0 in a "mini-derby" at Moss Lane, with Callum Gribbin scoring the only goal from a free-kick. The match featured a large proportion of local and English players, and was played in a stadium setting to provide the young players with experience similar to senior football. Nearly 1,000 spectators attended the free event. United's win leaves them two points behind league leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while City, dealing with injuries, have lost both playoff matches. The match showcased promising local talent for both teams.

Joe Hart, England and Manchester City goalkeeper, praised Italian veteran Gianluigi Buffon as a 'legend of the game' after Buffon earned his 147th international cap in a 1-1 draw with England. Hart, who achieved his own milestone by reaching 50 caps, described Buffon as an inspiration and expressed his desire to continue learning and increasing his number of international appearances. Hart is proud of his achievements so far and wants to keep playing well for club and country.

Chipotle is entering the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to offer delivery in 67 cities for online and mobile orders, charging a 9% service fee plus Postmates delivery fees starting at $5. The company previously resisted third-party delivery but is now following competitors like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King, who are also pursuing delivery. Celebrity customers, including Hillary Clinton and Marco Rubio, have recently been spotted at Chipotle locations.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, are publicly urging the Justice Department to remove the death penalty as a sentencing option for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was recently convicted on all charges related to the attack. In a Boston Globe opinion piece, they describe their family's ongoing suffering and argue that pursuing the death penalty would result in prolonged appeals and continued trauma. Instead, they support a sentence of life in prison without parole and waiving Tsarnaev’s right to appeals, stating this would help end their anguish and allow their family, and the community, to move forward.

A Boeing 747 jumbo jet has been converted into an extremely luxurious private home for an anonymous billionaire, at a cost of £400 million over three years. Normally able to seat up to 600 passengers, this custom-built plane is instead designed for a single owner and dozens of guests. Its features include multiple bedrooms (including a master suite and eight beds in an aeroloft), several lounges, a large dining room with an attached kitchen for a private chef, a conference room, and offices. The interior was redesigned to offer the feel of a high-end hotel, with artist impressions showing a plush, exclusive environment unlike any commercial aircraft. The project was depicted by Greenpoint Technologies.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket from Cape Canaveral carrying an uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station, successfully starting its mission after a weather delay. The company again attempted, but failed, to land the rocket’s first stage on a drone ship at sea, with the rocket landing too hard and tipping over. SpaceX founder Elon Musk aims to make rockets reusable to reduce costs. The Dragon capsule will deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies to the station, then return with more than 3,000 pounds of experiments and trash; this is SpaceX’s sixth mission to the ISS and the second attempt for this specific launch.

Priscilla Presley will act as a witness at the first wedding held at the new Elvis Presley’s Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas, located in the Westgate Hotel (formerly the Las Vegas Hilton, where Elvis performed over 830 shows). Through an NBC Today show contest, one Elvis-obsessed couple will win an “ultimate wedding” package, including the ceremony on April 23, reception, two-night hotel stay, airfare, and concert tickets. Priscilla, who helped design the chapel as part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis, insists the chapel is first-class with no Elvis impersonators allowed. Contestants must submit a video or photos explaining why they deserve to win. The winning couple will be announced next Monday.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League after a 2-0 win over Newcastle United, a match in which both he and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet made their 47th appearance of the season. After poor recent results, Henderson is optimistic as Liverpool are now four points behind Manchester City, who have been struggling. Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen scored for Liverpool, with Allen acknowledging Newcastle had a strong penalty claim. The win was seen as vital in the race for Champions League qualification.

Roma ended a four-month home winless streak by defeating Napoli 1-0 in a key Serie A match for Champions League contention. Miralem Pjanic scored in the 25th minute after a counter-attack, while goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made several crucial saves in the second half. The win moved Roma four points ahead of Lazio, while Napoli's winless run extended to five matches, leaving them in fifth place. Security was tight due to past violence, but no problems occurred. Roma played without injured captain Francesco Totti and Gervinho, while Napoli's Lorenzo Insigne returned from injury late in the match.

Doncaster Rovers' uninspired season continued with a 0-0 draw against Fleetwood Town, resulting in a tedious match that offered little excitement. The Doncaster media team highlighted the lack of action by releasing a very brief 27-second match highlights video, featuring only the kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

A man named Roland Giroux has developed a close bond with his blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid aquarium fish first bred in Taiwan around 1986. Unlike most marine pets, his fish enjoys and seeks out physical interaction, such as being stroked and massaged by Giroux’s hand inside the tank. The fish reacts positively, often returning for more contact and becoming frustrated if not played with daily. After removing two tankmates that bullied the fish, Giroux began hand-feeding it and noticed it became more sociable. He documents their interactions in videos, showing that the fish enjoys daily play and massage sessions.

Ben Stokes is known as a fiery and aggressive cricketer for England, with past incidents like breaking his wrist punching a locker showing his intense character. After a recent clash with Marlon Samuels, England coach Peter Moores advised Stokes on channeling his aggression positively, which Stokes did successfully. Stokes’ natural exuberance and competitiveness are seen as valuable, but it’s important that this aggression remains controlled and not forced. England wants Stokes in the team regularly to help him reach his potential, balancing his passionate approach with good man-management, while also considering team selection options such as playing an additional spinner.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12 at Cardiff City Stadium has sold out all 33,000 tickets. Both teams are top of Group B with 11 points from five games, but Belgium leads due to goal difference. Wales' recent 3-0 win over Israel—thanks in part to Gareth Bale—raised hopes of qualifying for their first major tournament since 1958. Despite high interest, the match will not move to the larger Millennium Stadium, as UEFA rules prohibit venue changes within 120 days of the match, and the Wales team prefers playing at the Cardiff City Stadium.

England coach John Peacock has announced the squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, where England are defending champions after beating Holland last year and qualified with a perfect record. They are in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland, opening against Italy on May 7. The squad includes players from various Premier League clubs such as Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo (Chelsea), Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi (Arsenal), with Mavididi and Willock called up for the first time. Liverpool’s Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold return after missing the last qualifying round. England’s subsequent matches are against Holland (May 10) and Ireland (May 13).

Manchester City are interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered a top talent and has also attracted interest from Arsenal and Barcelona. Patoulidis previously rejected Barcelona to focus on his studies. City are in talks with Anderlecht to agree on compensation, as manager Manuel Pellegrini aims to secure the promising player for the future.

A 33-year-old transgender escort, Vanessa Santillan, was found dead from head and neck injuries in a flat in Fulham, London, at the end of March. She was a Mexican national who had recently moved to London and had also worked in Paris and Miami. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death and later released on bail, pending further questioning. Police are appealing for information from anyone who had contact with Santillan before her death to help with the investigation, which remains ongoing.

A woman named Dawn, who has suffered seven miscarriages, accused her friend and housemate Jamie, a convicted burglar, of stealing £207 she and her partner had saved for a gravestone for their baby. During an appearance on The Jeremy Kyle show, a lie detector test confirmed Jamie had taken the money. Dawn was devastated by the betrayal and emotional about not being able to buy a headstone for her baby, Daniel James. Jamie had previously confessed to the theft in a Facebook message but blamed his girlfriend Carol. Dawn was left distraught and felt deeply let down by someone she trusted.

ISIS released more than 200 Yazidis—mostly women, children, and the ill or elderly—on Wednesday after previously killing, capturing, and displacing Yazidis in northern Iraq last summer. The release, reportedly coordinated with help from Arab tribal leaders, saw the freed Yazidis received by Kurdish Peshmerga forces and sent to Irbil. The exact reason for the release remains unclear. The Yazidis, a persecuted Kurdish-descended minority with an ancient, syncretic religion, suffered extreme violence and enslavement under ISIS, particularly after the militants seized Sinjar. International responses included aid drops, rescues, and U.S.-led airstrikes. About 500,000 Yazidis live in northern Iraq.

Harry Kane, after a remarkable season with Tottenham and breaking into the England team, has been nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Year awards. A new animation by Copa90 showcases some of his best goals and celebrations of the season, including his 20th Premier League goal and highlights like his long-range strike against Chelsea, a header against Arsenal, and his debut England goal. The video, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', was released ahead of the awards ceremony where Kane competes with players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers should remain Liverpool manager despite three seasons without a trophy and the likelihood of missing out on a top-four finish and Champions League qualification. Carragher recognizes the challenges Rodgers faced with new players and says improvement and better signings are needed for next season. Carragher, who received a Beacon Award for his community work in Merseyside, emphasizes his commitment to helping young people in deprived areas through his foundation, reflecting his desire to give back to his local community.

A four-year-old boy, James Hayward, had his plastic Nerf gun confiscated and was frisked by security at East Midlands Airport, as the toy was considered a security risk under UK regulations prohibiting items resembling guns. James’s father criticized the officers as over-zealous and called the situation “ludicrous.” The airport apologized for the inconvenience, noting they had offered to mail the toy home, and explained that their actions followed government-set security rules. After their trip to Lanzarote, the family bought James a replacement toy gun.

A man named Rich from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an online advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. He listed specific requirements for his ideal partner, including being a non-drinker and non-smoker, fit, attractive, reliable, honest, good with housework and cooking, and able to enjoy the outdoors and be “a princess when needed.” Rich described himself as 31 years old, athletic, tattooed, successful, property-owning, and generous with his partner. He offered benefits such as accommodation, possibly a company car, phone, laptop, gym membership, and was open to “all reasonable offers.” The ad excluded former partners, and attempts to contact Rich were unsuccessful.

Greg Dyke, chairman of the Football Association, is seeking to implement major changes to increase the number of home-grown players in club squads and tighten the definition of 'home-grown.' His proposals are opposed by the Premier League but have been publicly supported by five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren—who warn that failing to back Dyke's plans will harm the future of English football. Currently, only 36.8% of Premier League starters are eligible for England selection, highlighting the shrinking pool of top English talent. While acknowledging past shortcomings, the former managers stress that young talents like Harry Kane, Ross Barkley, and Raheem Sterling show promise, but greater opportunities are needed for English players to succeed at the highest level.

Demelza Poldark, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, quickly becomes a mother to a baby daughter in the latest episode of "Poldark," despite only recently announcing her pregnancy in the previous episode. The show skips over most of her pregnancy, with just minutes between her being eight months pregnant and giving birth. Fans noticed this rapid timeline, joking online about how quickly pregnancies progress on the show. Ross Poldark, played by Aidan Turner, is shown as devoted to Demelza and their new baby, disappointing the many viewers who admire him.

Leicester manager Nigel Pearson has urged his team to focus on their own performance and not worry about their relegation rivals, as they host Swansea just three points from safety after two consecutive wins. Despite remaining bottom of the Premier League, Leicester's recent victory, including Jamie Vardy’s late winner against West Brom, has given them hope of survival. Pearson emphasized that their fate is in their own hands and cautioned against over-optimism and becoming distracted by other teams’ results.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara set a new record for the longest mammal migration ever recorded, swimming nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico, according to Oregon State University scientists. This surpassed the previous record set by a humpback whale. Varvara's journey included visits to three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, surprising researchers who initially believed she was a western gray whale. The findings suggest some western gray whales may actually be eastern grays, which could affect current population estimates and our understanding of genetic differences between the two groups.

Overnight, about 1,000 feet of seabed rose up along the Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu, on Hokkaido Island, Japan, creating a new stretch of coastline as high as 50 feet above sea level. Geologists attribute the event to a nearby landslide caused by melting snow and ice, which shifted land and pushed the seabed upward. The newly exposed land, measuring approximately 1,000–1,640 feet long and 100 feet wide, surprised local residents who reported no tremors or sounds during the night. Authorities believe the event is unrelated to earthquakes and do not expect further expansion. Marine organisms remain attached to the new land surface.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied rumors about leaving Paris Saint-Germain, stating his happiness with the club and desire to sign a new contract despite a recent dispute with manager Laurent Blanc. He emphasized his love for PSG and readiness to play when called upon. However, speculation remains about his future as the club is linked with Barcelona's Dani Alves.

Carlos Tevez has expressed his desire to leave Juventus and return to his former club Boca Juniors in Argentina, despite his contract with the Italian champions running until 2016. Boca Juniors are close to completing the deal but require Tevez to terminate his Juventus contract first. Juventus, reluctant to lose their top scorer, have started looking for replacements. Tevez, who has scored 17 league goals this season, aims to finish his career at Boca. His departure will not affect his international prospects, according to Argentina manager Tata Martino.

Bayern Munich beat Porto 6-1 at the Allianz Arena, overturning a first-leg deficit to advance to the Champions League semi-finals. Bayern led 5-0 at half-time, with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and two from Robert Lewandowski. During the excitement, Bayern manager Pep Guardiola tore his trousers, exposing his underwear and joking about it after the match. The win established Bayern as dominant, leaving Porto overwhelmed.

A three-vehicle crash occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway near Fernvale, involving ten people, including four children. Several people were seriously injured: a 40-year-old man and a five-year-old boy were airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital, followed by a 27-year-old woman and a six-year-old girl. Six others, including an infant, were transported to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for assessment. The highway was closed with diversions in place, and emergency crews used hydraulic equipment to free a trapped person.

Arsenal, currently second in the Premier League and 10 points behind leaders Chelsea with six games left, are preparing for a crucial match at home on Sunday. Player Mesut Ozil is excited for the upcoming game and has shared on Instagram his new Apple Watch, drawing comparisons to the Knight Rider TV show. Ozil, who has scored four goals in 25 games this season, is expected to start. Arsenal have been boosted by the return of Jack Wilshere from a long injury; club legend Ray Parlour believes Wilshere can be the club's future if he remains fit, though his injury record raises concerns.

Mark Clattenburg will referee the Manchester derby at Old Trafford, despite controversy over him sending off three United and City players this season and past accusations of bias towards United. He has only issued two red cards in the Premier League this season, both to United players (Tyler Blackcett and Luke Shaw). City captain Vincent Kompany is suspended for an upcoming Belgium match after a recent red card. The derby is significant, as United have overtaken City in the table after City's recent poor form. Clattenburg will be assisted by Simon Beck, Jake Collin, and fourth official Jonathan Moss. Clattenburg is generally regarded as one of the Premier League's top referees.

Bob Katter, federal MP, made a controversial statement accusing the Queensland Government of viewing embattled MP Billy Gordon as "a little black puppet on a string," after Gordon was accused of domestic violence and left the Labor Party, but decided to remain in parliament as an independent. Katter, who has faced racism himself, criticized the assumption that Gordon would resign, suggesting racial overtones in the Government's actions. His remarks sparked social media criticism over his terminology, but Katter defended his choice of words based on his personal experiences and argued his intent was to highlight perceived racism.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Illinois with cerebral palsy, creates dance videos to challenge stereotypes about disabilities and inspire others. Despite facing bullying and assumptions that she is very different, Dayna wants people to see her as just like anyone else. She hopes her videos, including one set to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off," will encourage viewers to think before judging. Defying doctors' expectations that she might never walk, Dayna now dances, drives, attends college, and has started motivational speaking at local schools to spread her positive message.

Orlando City are interested in signing Manchester United’s Javier Hernandez, who is also attracting attention from several European clubs after a difficult loan spell at Real Madrid. Orlando, with a large Latin-American fanbase, see Hernandez as both a commercial draw and a popular player alongside captain Kaka. Manchester United are open to selling Hernandez for around £8 million, with English clubs (Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton) and European clubs (Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, Inter Milan) also interested. Additionally, Manchester United have made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old Andreas Pereira, who has interest from various European clubs after rejecting their initial offer.

A group of at least three suspects attempted to carjack a man at a South Los Angeles gas station around 12:15am on Saturday. After an argument, the suspects poured gasoline on the man's white Dodge Charger, which had two passengers inside, and set it on fire. No one was injured, but the car was completely burned. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as arson, and the suspects are still at large. Surveillance footage is being used in the investigation.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from Lamoni, Iowa, surrendered his state license after admitting to accepting sex as payment, performing exorcisms on patients, and advising them to stop taking prescribed medications. The Iowa Board of Chiropractic detailed charges against him, and Manuel agreed not to seek reinstatement for at least 10 years, unless he proves the issues no longer exist. Despite these actions, he received perfect patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com from three reviews. He has not worked at his former practice for some time, and contact attempts to his home and practice were unsuccessful.

A Russian SU-27 fighter jet intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane in an "unsafe and unprofessional manner" over the Baltic Sea in international airspace north of Poland, according to the Pentagon. The U.S. protested the incident, citing aggressive maneuvers by the Russian jet. Russia claimed the U.S. plane was approaching its border with its transponder off, a claim the U.S. denies. This is not the first such incident, as a similar event occurred last year. The U.S. plans to file a diplomatic complaint with Russia. Russian and U.S. aircraft frequently encounter each other in areas near Europe and the Pacific.

A sniper rifle belonging to an FBI agent was stolen from his car in the parking lot of the Marriott Springhill Suites in Salt Lake City, just days before President Obama’s visit to Utah. The rifle, secured in a locked case and attached to the car with padlocks and chains, was taken overnight after thieves broke a car window and used a rope, apparently with another vehicle, to rip the case free. Other items, including bags and clothing, were also stolen, though some were later recovered nearby. The rifle remains missing, and the theft occurred near the state’s FBI office and before a presidential visit. The hotel lacked surveillance cameras, and the rifle’s serial number was entered into a national database. Police are unsure if the agent’s car was specifically targeted.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of killing his elderly neighbour Terrence Freebody in Canberra in July 2012. A jury was told Costa was believed to be suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse at the time. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen found evidence of Costa’s declining mental state before and during the incident, citing mood fluctuations and confusion. Prosecutor Shane Drumgold suggested Costa was faking memory loss, but Mullen disagreed, saying Costa likely suffered dementia leading up to the event. Costa’s mental state is crucial to the case, as a not guilty verdict is possible if his unstable mindset at the time is proven.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley after he missed a penalty in their 1-0 win over Burnley, noting Barkley was allowed to take the kick instead of regular taker Leighton Baines, who has a strong record. The miss revived memories of a previous penalty controversy involving Kevin Mirallas. Martinez explained he trusts several players to take penalties based on how they feel, praised Barkley’s responsibility, and emphasized that the miss was not costly as Mirallas later scored the winning goal.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on Holland America Line’s ms Ryndam cruise ship in San Juan, Puerto Rico, in what appears to be a murder-suicide. The cruise line secured the cabin and informed authorities, including the FBI, who are investigating the incident. The ship, on a 14-day Caribbean cruise from Tampa, had the bodies discovered by cleaning staff.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has successfully led Curacao to the second round of 2018 World Cup qualifying in CONCACAF. Curacao advanced after drawing 2-2 with Montserrat (winning 4-3 on aggregate), with Charlton Vicento scoring a late goal to secure progression. Kluivert’s team had won the first leg 2-1. Curacao will play Cuba next. Kluivert has a personal connection to Curacao through his mother and was previously Holland's assistant coach at the 2014 World Cup.

Esteban Cambiasso, a footballer with an illustrious career winning major European trophies at clubs like Inter Milan and Real Madrid, considers helping Leicester City avoid relegation from the Premier League as significant as any trophy he’s won. Despite Leicester being seven points from safety with eight games left, Cambiasso remains determined and optimistic. He quickly became a key player after joining Leicester on a one-year deal, is happy at the club, and may stay beyond this season.

A 23-year-old woman named Gemma risks being banned from seeing her two young children by her mother, Debbie, due to her ongoing drinking, partying, and alleged theft. Debbie has cared for the children since they were infants, after Gemma gave up caring for them. Debbie claims Gemma is unfit as a mother, preferring partying and substance use, and suspects her of stealing to fund her lifestyle. Despite Gemma's denials, a lie detector indicated she had stolen from her family. As a result, Debbie is preparing to bar Gemma from her home and from seeing her children, whom Debbie continues to raise.

Chelsea took a 1-0 lead over Manchester United after Eden Hazard scored, following a move that began with a strong challenge by John Terry on Radamel Falcao. The Sky Sports pundits—Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness—all agreed that Terry fouled Falcao during the build-up and that play should have been stopped for the foul. Despite the quality of Hazard's goal, the consensus among the analysts was that Terry’s challenge on Falcao was not properly penalized.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott’s tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway, but all passengers—including Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver—were safely evacuated. The fire began after a rear tire blew out and destroyed the back lounge of the bus, though Scott’s Bible survived. The other two band members were not on the bus. Lady Antebellum is scheduled to perform at the upcoming Academy of Country Music Awards.

Dr Adrian Quarterman from Dundee University is developing a system that uses space lasers to convert sunlight into energy, which could then be beamed down to Earth to power homes—even in less sunny places like Scotland or in disaster-hit areas. The system uses satellites covered in mirrors to harvest sunlight, which is then converted into laser light and directed at solar panels on Earth to boost their energy. Initial trials in Scotland were successful, and further testing is planned in Portugal. Unlike science fiction lasers, these would not be powerful enough to cause harm. A separate Japanese project aims to use space lasers on the International Space Station to clear space debris, also at low power. While Dr Quarterman acknowledges a slight risk depending on who controls the satellites, the technology is not intended for use as a weapon.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile with a history of obsession with young girls, has gone missing from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire. He was detained under the Mental Health Act after being convicted in August for sexually touching a three-year-old girl and possessing indecent images of children. Munden, who has autism and mild learning difficulties, was last seen leaving the hospital on Tuesday evening and may have altered his appearance by shaving his beard. Police have launched a manhunt and are urgently appealing for information about his whereabouts.

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano to repay over $2.6 million in gifts to Donald Sterling’s wife, Rochelle “Shelly” Sterling, who claimed in court that Stiviano targeted wealthy older men and received expensive gifts and property from Donald Sterling using the couple’s money. Stiviano argued the gifts were legitimate, but the court’s decision means Shelly Sterling can recover damages from recipients of such gifts. Donald Sterling had previously lost ownership of the Los Angeles Clippers and was banned from the NBA after recordings of his racist comments to Stiviano were made public.

Thierry Henry has criticised Arsenal's recent transfer activity, stating that the club needs to sign four top players—a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and striker—to have a chance of winning the Premier League. Speaking after Arsenal's goalless draw with Chelsea, Henry questioned whether Olivier Giroud is good enough as the club’s main striker and suggested Arsenal should buy players of similar quality to Chelsea’s recent signings. He believes strengthening the team's spine is essential for competing for the title.

A young woman testified in Sydney's District Court about the severe impact of years of sexual abuse by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn, who has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim described her struggles with depression, self-harm, attempted suicide, and fears about future relationships as a result of the abuse, which she kept secret until Van Ryn was caught. The hearing is ongoing.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is feeling increasingly positive as he nears a first-team return after more than a year out with a serious knee injury. Having last played for the senior team in March 2014, he recently completed 90 minutes for Arsenal's Under-21s, signaling he is over his injury and ready for future games.

A 23-year-old accountant, Jacob Phillips, died after falling down a 70ft cliff in Penarth, South Wales, while fleeing a taxi driver to avoid paying the fare after a night out drinking with friends. Phillips and his friends exited the taxi claiming they would use an ATM, but instead ran off in different directions because they didn't have enough money. In the darkness, Phillips leapt over a fence and accidentally fell off a cliff, where he was found dead the next morning. An inquest ruled his death accidental, noting he was disoriented and unaware of the danger. Phillips had returned to Wales for Christmas and was staying with his mother at the time.

Thousands of holidaymakers affected by last summer’s passport delays have largely not received compensation, even though the Passport Office made a £42 million profit during the disruption and managers received up to £3,500 in bonuses. Despite a massive backlog and urgent calls for compensation, only 2,191 claims were approved between April and January, totaling £203,066, with most applicants receiving nothing or very little. Ministers refused to compensate all affected families, arguing it would set a precedent, and calls for broader refunds were rejected.

A semi-detached house in Horfield, Bristol, largely unchanged since the 1930s, is up for auction with a guide price of £200,000–£250,000. The home retains many original features, including stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, a mint green and black bathroom, wood-panelled hall, vintage kitchen cupboards, retro food jars, and a brick open fireplace. While it is double glazed, most other elements remain untouched, making it appealing to collectors and antique enthusiasts. Some worry renovation costs may deter developers. The property will be auctioned on April 30 at Bristol’s County Ground.

Colin Kaepernick became the San Francisco 49ers' starting quarterback during the 2012 season after Alex Smith's concussion, and led the team to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and was released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans, lived there in her early years, then moved to Texas and later San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 through the Lincoln Tunnel into Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language television network owned by Comcast through NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in East London and Essex, attended Stanway School where he met Graham Coxon and formed Blur, whose debut album 'Leisure' came out in 1991 to mixed reviews. Blur drew from various music genres. Albarn released his debut solo studio album 'Everyday Robots' on 28 April 2014, co-produced by Richard Russell, featuring collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and others.
Mogadishu, also known as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia, and it hosts many important national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by the American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails from their debut EP, Broken (1992).
Andrew Kevin Walker, born August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA award.

The 2007 film "Shooter" follows Bob Lee Swagger, a Force Recon veteran framed for murder by a rogue private military company. The "Shooter" TV series stars Ryan Phillippe as Swagger, an expert marksman living in exile who returns to action after discovering a plot to kill the president.
House (also called House, M.D.) is an American medical drama television series that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was found guilty in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy for the deaths of seven people—including actress Sharon Tate—carried out by his followers at his instruction. He was also convicted for the murders of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. After his arrest, recordings of songs he wrote and performed were released commercially.

Sean Penn (born August 17, 1960) is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist who began acting on television before making his film debut in Taps (1981). He gained critical attention through various roles in the 1980s and 1990s, especially in crime dramas. Penn became a prominent leading actor with Dead Man Walking (1995), earning his first Academy Award nomination. He received further Oscar nominations for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001), and won the Best Actor Oscar for Mystic River (2003) and Milk (2008).

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman (1908–2001) was an Australian cricketer widely acknowledged as the greatest batsman of all time. After retiring, he remained influential in cricket as an administrator, selector, and writer for thirty years.

L.A. Reid has held top executive positions in the music industry, including chairman and CEO of Epic Records, president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is a drummer best known for playing with Rage Against the Machine (1991–2000; 2007–11) and Audioslave (2001–07). He started with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage Against the Machine in 1991. As of 2016, he plays in Prophets of Rage with several other musicians. The passage also notes that Rage is a separate German heavy metal band founded in 1984.

"The Millers" was a multi-camera series that aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015, running for 34 episodes over two seasons. CBS cancelled the show on November 14, 2014, after four episodes of the second season had aired.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (1933–2006) was the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995 and a Democrat known for her outspoken feminism and wit. She gained national attention as state treasurer by delivering the keynote at the 1988 Democratic National Convention and lost her re-election bid in 1994 to George W. Bush. She was the second female governor of Texas. Ann Richards (1935–1982), also mentioned, was an American jazz singer and the wife of Stan Kenton.
Drake Bell independently released an EP titled "A Reminder" in 2011.

Boardwalk is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman and directed by Verona. Janet Leigh, an American actress, singer, dancer, and author, starred in the film and wrote four books, including two novels, between 1984 and 2002.

Simón Bolívar, known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader who played a key role in helping Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama gain independence from Spanish rule.
The Bermuda Triangle, or Devil's Triangle, is a region in the western North Atlantic Ocean where several aircraft and ships are reported to have disappeared under mysterious circumstances.

Colin Kaepernick became the San Francisco 49ers' starting quarterback in 2012 after Alex Smith’s concussion, led the team to a Super Bowl appearance that season (losing to the Ravens), and in his first full season as starter in 2013, took the 49ers to the NFC Championship, where they lost to the Seahawks.
"Marnie" is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is a marketing communication that uses openly sponsored, nonpersonal messages to promote products, services, or ideas. Unlike personal selling, it is not directed at individuals and is delivered through various mass media, including both traditional (newspapers, TV, radio) and new media (websites, blogs, text messages).
"Private Lives" is originally a 1930 three-act comedy of manners by Noël Coward, and was later adapted into a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.
Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton, was a British Conservative politician who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 10 January 1957 to 19 October 1963.

Aristotle (384–322 BC) was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist from Stagira, Chalkidice. He joined Plato’s Academy in Athens at seventeen or eighteen and stayed until age thirty-seven. After Plato’s death, Aristotle left Athens and, starting in 343 BC, tutored Alexander the Great at the request of Philip II of Macedon.
David Mordechai Packouz, born in 1982, is a former American arms dealer who later invented the BeatBuddy guitar pedal drum machine and is now the CEO of the music technology company Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons, winning five NBA championships—including one and a Finals MVP award as a rookie. He retired multiple times, briefly returning in 1996. Off the court, he became a successful businessman, recognized as one of America's most influential black businessmen by Ebony magazine in 2009, and was also a part-owner of the Lakers.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles in 1994, consisting of Jack Black and Kyle Gass. They have released three albums: Tenacious D (2001), The Pick of Destiny (2006), and Rize of the Fenix (2012). They gained popularity in 1997 through their television series and by supporting major rock acts.

James VI and I (1566–1625) was King of Scotland from 1567 and became King of England and Ireland in 1603, ruling all three kingdoms in personal union. Although he successfully achieved many of his goals in Scotland, he faced significant challenges in England, including conflicts with the English Parliament and the Gunpowder Plot of 1605. He supported the idea of a single parliament for England and Scotland, but both kingdoms remained sovereign states with separate institutions during his reign.

Big Brother 2017 (Big Brother 18) is the eighteenth series of the British reality TV show, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley. Marcus Bentley, born in 1967, is a British actor and broadcaster best known for narrating the UK version of Big Brother since 2000, first on Channel 4 and then on Channel 5. His distinctive Geordie-accented voice has made him widely recognized in Britain.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state in Germany, bordering four other German states and the countries of Poland and the Czech Republic. It is the tenth largest and sixth most populous of Germany's sixteen states, with an area of 18,413 km² and 4 million people. Saxony has a history spanning over a millennium and, along with Saale-Unstrut, is one of the northernmost wine regions in Europe and one of only two German wine regions located in the former East Germany.
East End Park was a former major league baseball park in Cincinnati's East End neighborhood, and "In the End" is a song by the American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown began her solo career by releasing "I Want You Back" with Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

Mohra is a 1994 Indian action thriller directed by Rajiv Rai, featuring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah in lead roles. Released on July 1, 1994, it became the second highest grossing Indian film of that year and received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Raveena Tandon took over the female lead after Divya Bharti’s death. The film is also notable for its popular songs.
A song titled "Hourglass" is by the British electronic duo Disclosure, and "Hourglass" is also the title of singer-songwriter James Taylor's fourteenth studio album.
Shane Black (born December 16, 1961) is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor, known for writing the 1987 film Lethal Weapon and directing Kiss Kiss Bang Bang in 2005.
A View to a Kill (1985) is the fourteenth film in the James Bond series and the seventh and final Bond film starring Roger Moore as James Bond.

Papua is Indonesia’s largest and easternmost province, covering most of western New Guinea. It was formerly known as Irian Jaya (and earlier as West Irian or Irian Barat), and once included all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus likely died of natural causes, but there were unconfirmed rumors that his wife Livia poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez launched her music career in 1999 with the album On the 6 and became the first woman to have a number one album and film in the same week in 2001. Her relationship with Ben Affleck influenced her third album and coincided with the poorly received film Gigli. She then married Marc Anthony, achieved box office success with Shall We Dance?, and had twins in 2008. After a career downturn, Lopez returned to prominence in 2011 as an American Idol judge and released "On the Floor," one of the best-selling singles ever.

A working animal is a usually domesticated animal trained by humans to perform tasks, such as assistance, pulling loads, milking, or herding. While they are typically domesticated, wild animals may also rarely be trained for work, but usually just for novelty or entertainment, as they lack the necessary temperament of domesticated animals.

"Billboard Dad" is a 1998 American direct-to-video comedy film directed by Alan Metter and starring Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen. "Top Latin Albums" is an important music chart by Billboard magazine for Spanish-language albums in the US. "Regional Mexican Albums" is a weekly, genre-specific Billboard chart for regional Mexican music in the US.

Vedam (English: Chant) is a 2010 Telugu-language Indian drama film written and directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi, featuring actors Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham.
Men in Black II (MIIB) is a 2002 American science fiction action comedy film starring Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub, and Rip Torn.

Sancho Panza is a fictional character from the 1605 novel Don Quixote by Miguel de Cervantes. He serves as Don Quixote’s squire and is known for his humorous and witty remarks, called "sanchismos," which include ironic proverbs and earthy humor.
The Adventures of Pluto Nash is a 2002 Australian-American science fiction action comedy film starring Eddie Murphy in a dual role and directed by Ron Underwood.
The world premiere of Hedda Gabler, attended by Ibsen, was held on 31 January 1891 at the Residenztheater in Munich.
Brazzers is a pornographic production company based in Montreal, Canada.
Timothy Simon Roth, born 14 May 1961, is an English actor and director.

Juventus Football Club, commonly known as Juve, is a professional Italian football club from Turin, founded in 1897 by young local students including first president Eugenio Canfari. It is the second oldest active football club in Italy after Genoa, has worn black and white stripes since 1903, and currently plays at the 41,507-capacity Juventus Stadium.

Viola Davis played supporting and minor roles in films such as Kate & Leopold (2001) and Far from Heaven (2002), as well as in the television series Law & Order: Special Victims Unit during the late 1990s and early 2000s.

Jenna Jameson, born April 9, 1974, is an American entrepreneur, webcam model, and former pornographic film actress widely known as "The Queen of Porn." She began her career in erotic videos in 1993 after working as a stripper and glamour model.
The New Orleans Pelicans are a team in the National Basketball Association (NBA), competing in the league's Western Conference Southwest Division.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000, first broadcast via closed-circuit and later pay-per-view, organized by the NWA and later WCW. Traditionally, major wrestling events were held on Thanksgiving and Christmas, mainly at Greensboro Coliseum. The 1985 Starrcade was the third event, the 1987 show was the fifth, and the 1997 event was the fifteenth annual Starrcade.
Jack Ryan Falahee (born February 20, 1989) is an American actor known for his roles as Connor Walsh on ABC's How to Get Away with Murder and Benjamin Stringfellow on PBS's Mercy Street.

"Don't Say No" is the debut extended play (mini album) by Seohyun, a South Korean singer and actress born on June 28, 1991. Matthew David McConaughey (born November 4, 1969) is an American actor who, since 2011, has focused on dramatic roles in films such as The Lincoln Lawyer, Bernie, Killer Joe, The Paperboy, Mud, Magic Mike, The Wolf of Wall Street, Dallas Buyers Club, Interstellar, The Sea of Trees, and Free State of Jones. The film Mud (2012) stars McConaughey along with Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon.

Robert Palmer is known for his books (notably Deep Blues), music journalism for the New York Times and Rolling Stone, producing blues recordings and the Deep Blues film soundtrack, and for playing clarinet with the 1960s band the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum (1912–1986) was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer, best known for taking over as leader of the Mount Rushmore National Memorial project after the death of his father, Gutzon Borglum, in 1941. Gutzon Borglum designed and led the Mount Rushmore project from 1927 until his death, after which Lincoln Borglum completed the work.

"Underdog" is a film directed by Frederik Du Chau, written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. The cast includes Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, with voice roles by Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The 100 (TV series) follows a group of teens from a space habitat called "The Ark"—including Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, and others—who are among the first people to return to Earth after a nuclear apocalypse. The series also focuses on adults from the Ark, such as Dr. Abby Griffin, council member Marcus Kane, and Chancellor Thelonious Jaha.

The Concert for Bangladesh was a pioneering and influential humanitarian aid project that, despite later financial problems, successfully raised awareness and funds, and served as a valuable example for future efforts such as Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam is considered one of India's influential filmmakers, credited with revolutionizing the Tamil film industry and changing the profile of Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine was stated by Stephen A. Douglas during the second Lincoln-Douglas debate in Freeport, Illinois, on August 27, 1858. The Lincoln-Douglas debates were a series of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln and Stephen Douglas during their U.S. Senate race in Illinois, with topics such as slavery drawing large crowds due to their national significance.

Easy A is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck, written by Bert V. Royal, and starring Emma Stone along with an ensemble cast including Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice (born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien, October 4, 1941) is an American author known for gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. She began her writing career with "Interview with the Vampire" in 1976 and started writing sequels in the 1980s. Initially receiving mixed reviews, her popularity grew in the 1980s. She was married to Stan Rice for 41 years until his death in 2002.

Camden is a city in Camden County, New Jersey, with a 2010 population of 77,344, making it the 12th most populous municipality in the state. At the start of the twentieth century, its population was mostly European immigrants.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for the 2013 American erotic thriller-drama film The Canyons, which was directed by Paul Schrader and received critical derision.

The Lincoln-Douglas Debates were a series of seven debates in 1858 between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate, and Stephen Douglas, the Democratic incumbent Senator, held in seven towns across Illinois.

Homer is the name given by the ancient Greeks to the author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, which are central works of ancient Greek literature. "The Thicket" is a mystery/suspense novel by American author Joe R. Lansdale.
Christopher Scott Kyle (1974–2013) was a U.S. Navy SEAL veteran and sniper who was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range in Texas on February 2, 2013.

Audioslave was a four-member band made up of Soundgarden's Chris Cornell and Rage Against the Machine's Tom Morello, Tim Commerford, and Brad Wilk. Brad Wilk, best known as the drummer for both Rage Against the Machine and Audioslave, began his career with Greta and co-founded Rage in 1991 with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha. As of 2016, Wilk plays in Prophets of Rage with Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord. Rage Against the Machine was formed in 1991 and includes Zack de la Rocha, Tim Commerford, Tom Morello, and Brad Wilk.

Janelle Monáe Robinson (born December 1, 1985) is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model signed to Wondaland Arts Society and Atlantic Records. In 2010, she released her first full-length, critically acclaimed studio album, The ArchAndroid, which is a concept album sequel to her first EP and was released by Bad Boy Records.
"Winter's Tale" is a novel written by Mark Helprin and published in 1983.

The passage states that Lake Providence is a town and the parish seat of East Carroll Parish in northeastern Louisiana, United States. It also provides information about the University of Mississippi, noting that about 55% of its undergraduates and 60% overall are from Mississippi, 23% are minorities, and international students come from 90 nations.
The series "Flaked" was renewed in July 2016 for a six-episode second season, which is scheduled to premiere on June 2, 2017.
Aaron Burr was elected twice to the New York State Assembly, served as New York State Attorney General, was a U.S. senator from New York, and ultimately became vice president.

The Soyuz rocket was commissioned to launch Soyuz spacecraft for the Soviet human spaceflight program, starting with 8 unmanned test flights and then 19 manned launches. Designed by the Korolyov Design Bureau in the 1960s, Soyuz succeeded the Voskhod spacecraft, was initially developed for Soviet lunar programs, and is still in service today.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine broke up after de la Rocha quit due to tensions within the band. De la Rocha began a solo career, while the other members formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell, releasing three albums before Audioslave disbanded in 2007. That same year, Rage Against the Machine reunited and performed at Coachella. Their fourth studio album, Renegades, was released on December 5, 2000.

The S&P BSE SENSEX is a free-float market-weighted index of 30 prominent companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange, including Tata Motors, which is also listed on the National Stock Exchange of India and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia, with a population of about 92.7 million—making it the 14th most populous country in the world and ninth in Asia. It borders China, Laos, Cambodia, Thailand (across the Gulf of Thailand), and is near the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia (across the South China Sea).
