Since 2000, it has had one of the world’s highest economic growth rates, and in 2011 had the highest Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies. Vietnam is one of four remaining one-party socialist states officially endorsing communism.
"Dreamer" is a 2005 American sports drama film, written and directed by John Gatins in his directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary whose dramatic violent acts against the British and execution at age 23 made him a folk hero of the Indian independence movement, and he became especially popular after his death.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut in the 2016 Hindi biographical sports drama film "Dangal," directed by Nitesh Tiwari and starring Aamir Khan.

James VI and I (1566–1625) was King of Scotland from 1567 and became King of England and Ireland in 1603, ruling all three kingdoms until his death. Although Scotland and England remained separate sovereign states, James ruled them in personal union and strongly supported the idea of a single parliament for both countries. During his reign in England, he faced many difficulties with Parliament.

Danielle Cormack, born 26 December 1970, is a New Zealand stage and screen actress. She was an original cast member of Shortland Street and is known for roles in Xena: Warrior Princess, The Cult, Legend of the Seeker, Separation City, Rake, and Underbelly: Razor. Her most notable recent role was Bea Smith in Wentworth, which she left in 2016 after four years.
Rob Sheridan (born October 11, 1979) is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer, chiefly recognized for his significant work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade starred in several films including Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2. Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser is a 2015 American comedy film directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett, born August 16, 1958, is an American actress.

Artpop received mixed reviews from critics but was commercially successful, debuting at number one on the US Billboard 200 with 258,000 first-week sales, becoming Gaga's second consecutive US number-one album. It sold 757,000 copies in the US and 2.3 million copies worldwide in 2013, making it the ninth best-selling album of that year.
In 2006, the Chili Peppers released the album Stadium Arcadium, which was their fifth and final album with guitarist John Frusciante. Frusciante confirmed his departure from the band in 2009.
Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, implemented policies known as Thatcherism; she remains a controversial but highly influential figure in British history, with ongoing debates about her policies.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan (born February 5, 1964) is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author who has also written weekly columns on various topics for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker, an English actor, has also narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series in addition to his acting roles.

Valencia is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia and is the third largest city in Spain after Madrid and Barcelona, with about 800,000 people in its administrative center and a metropolitan area population between 1.7 and 2.5 million. The Valencian Community is an autonomous region of Spain, with Valencia as its capital.
Buffy Summers was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The series "Make It or Break It" ended with its third season, which was announced on April 26, 2012. The series finale aired on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition is a sub-field of computational linguistics that creates technologies for computers to recognize and convert spoken language into text, drawing on linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Applications include voice user interfaces, call routing, appliance control, search, data entry, document preparation, speech-to-text, and aircraft systems. Recent advances are driven by deep learning methods, widely adopted by major tech companies such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, and others.

Richard Alf (1952–2012) was an American businessman and comic book store owner who co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International and served as its chairman starting in 1970. The convention, originally named the Golden State Comic Book Convention, was founded in 1970 by Alf and others, including Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry, and was later renamed the San Diego Comic Book Convention.
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which originally starred Bruce Lee as the lead character.

France's Dubuisson and South Africa's Van Zyl lead on 16 under par after shooting 67s. Rory McIlroy is one shot behind, tied with Kiradech Aphibarnrat at 15 under after his third successive 67, which included an eagle. McIlroy, recovering from an ankle injury, is aiming for his first title since May and is leading the Race to Dubai. English golfers Chris Wood and Richard Bland are fifth and seventh, respectively.

Sheikh Ali Salman, leader of the opposition group al-Wefaq, stressed to the BBC that meaningful national dialogue in Bahrain requires the government to offer real solutions and include representatives of the royal family—specifically reformist Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa. While hardliners led by the unelected Prime Minister oppose dialogue, Salman supports negotiation as necessary, though he notes many young protesters have lost faith in the process. He recalled that a seven-point reform plan was agreed with the crown prince before GCC troops intervened in March 2011, halting progress. Sheikh Salman called for the US and UK to apply more direct public pressure on Bahrain for reforms and human rights. He maintained that peaceful demonstrations would continue despite government bans and insisted that the release of jailed opposition leaders is essential for successful dialogue.

Christopher Hogwood, a leading conductor and influential figure in the early-music movement, died at his Cambridge home after a long illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, directing it worldwide for 30 years and overseeing over 200 recordings, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. He was known for his acclaimed 1980 recording of Handel's Messiah. Hogwood held significant teaching and leadership roles at institutions such as Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell, and was praised for his generosity, scholarship, and impact on musicians globally. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service planned.

In the year ending March, Scotland recorded 57 homicide victims, five fewer than the previous year and the lowest annual total since 1976—half the number from nine years ago. As of March 31, 2016, only one 2015-16 homicide case was unresolved. Sharp instruments, mainly knives, were involved in 51% of the cases. About 31% of accused individuals were under the influence of alcohol or drugs. Authorities highlighted the role of education, enforcement, and community support in reducing homicide rates but emphasized continued vigilance. However, concerns remain as sexual crime rates are at a 45-year high and violent crime, including attempted murder and serious assault, has recently risen by 27%. Homicide data from previous years have also been subject to revision.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland, making them the first team to be beaten by Sunderland in the Premier League that season. Dan Gosling scored Bournemouth's first goal in three games, but Sunderland equalized and then won with a penalty, despite being down to ten men. Manager Howe expressed disappointment at missed scoring opportunities, noting the team's recent struggles despite creating many chances, and emphasized the importance of moving forward from the defeat.

Mr Abbott stated that the only way to stop deaths at sea is to "stop the boats," referring to Australia's policy of detaining boat migrants and sending them to offshore camps for resettlement elsewhere. The New York Times criticized this approach as "brutal," "inhumane," and contrary to Australia's tradition of welcoming refugees. Mr Abbott defended the policy, saying it has stopped illegal boat arrivals and related deaths. He also caused controversy by saying Islamic State (IS) is worse than the Nazis, a comparison condemned by Australian Jewish groups, who argued IS's crimes, while horrific, are not comparable to the Holocaust. Mr Abbott later maintained his comments but said he was not trying to "rank evil."

The United States blamed Russia and the Syrian government for increasing attacks on civilians in Aleppo and warned it would halt talks unless Russia stopped its bombing. After continued violence and bombing of civilian infrastructure, including hospitals, the US suspended its participation in talks with Russia aimed at maintaining a ceasefire. The US accused Russia of failing to uphold agreements and targeting civilian areas, while Russia denied these claims and accused the US of not fulfilling its own commitments and shifting blame for the truce's collapse. Despite suspending talks and withdrawing personnel, both countries said they would continue limited communication to avoid clashes during counter-terrorism operations.

The government supported a Policy Exchange report suggesting that selling high-value vacant social homes could raise £4.5bn a year, potentially funding 80,000–170,000 new social homes and reducing the social housing waiting list by about 500,000. The report defines expensive social housing as properties worth more than the regional average and estimates that selling 28,500 vacant homes annually could generate these funds. Supporters argue this would create the biggest social housing program since the 1970s, but critics, including Labour and housing groups, warn it could force low-income families out of affluent areas and break up communities. Labour proposes using a bank bonus tax to build more affordable homes, while the government emphasizes making efficient use of social housing stock through reforms and investments.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died in Swansea, which is experiencing a measles epidemic with 942 cases. Although he had measles, it is unclear if this was the main cause of death; further tests are being conducted. He had recently been treated for asthma before becoming unwell and developing a rash. Since the outbreak began, 83 people have needed hospital treatment, and Mr Colfer-Williams’ family is unsure how he contracted measles, as no close relatives have it and his daughter is vaccinated.
Vincent Hudson, 54, of Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offence against a boy under 16, alleged to have occurred in 2001. He is due to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Gateshead and Guiseley drew 1-1 in the National League. Guiseley took the lead in the 15th minute through Jake Lawlor, but Wes York equalized for Gateshead in the 62nd minute. Both teams extended their unbeaten runs, with Gateshead now unbeaten in nine matches and Guiseley in five. The match included several substitutions and yellow cards for both sides.

Bristol Sport Ltd plans to increase stadium capacity by replacing two stands, instead of building a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which has been delayed. The redevelopment was approved by Bristol City Council in November, and majority shareholder Steve Lansdown stated the club will start work if there is no judicial review by March, with construction beginning in May.

Cuadrilla has suspended shale gas drilling (fracking) operations near Poulton-le-Fylde after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months. The British Geological Survey (BGS) will analyze the data before a decision on resuming is made. Fracking has caused concerns about earthquakes and environmental risks, with two small quakes recorded in Lancashire since March. The BGS confirmed both tremors occurred near the drilling site and shared similar characteristics; they are monitoring the situation, noting that injecting pressurized fluids underground can trigger earthquakes. UK officials argue that strict regulation could mitigate such problems, as seen in the US where fracking is controversial.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old busker from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud for playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes in April 2015, giving the impression he was collecting money for the charity. He was cleared of two other fraud charges. Carpenter claimed he was only busking and had used the banner as a tribute, with permission to display it but not to collect funds for the campaign. He will be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0, with goals from Grant Ward, Luke Varney (after a mistake by QPR goalkeeper Alex Smithies), and Tom Lawrence. Ipswich had previously struggled to score but created many chances in this match. QPR showed little attacking threat, only coming close when substitute Sandro hit the post. The win moved Ipswich up to 14th place in the Championship, above QPR, who dropped to 15th. Managers Mick McCarthy (Ipswich) and Ian Holloway (QPR) both reflected on their teams’ performances, with McCarthy praising his players and Holloway criticizing his team’s response after the second goal.

Wells, 23, performed well in last season's T20 Blast with 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66. He praised the club's positive direction and the elite environment fostered by the coaches.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured a second consecutive win by defeating third-placed Chinnor 29-12. Their front row and front five played a crucial role, making over 70 tackles. In their next eight games, the Reds will mostly face teams ranked below them, except for a match against the league leaders. Coach Churcher praised the team's effort but noted there is still room for improvement, emphasizing the need to build on their recent performance.

Police allege that 28-year-old Nazrul, a Bangladeshi citizen, raped a 74-year-old nun during an attack on a convent in Ranaghat on 14 March, where money was also stolen and the building ransacked. He was arrested in Kolkata, marking the sixth arrest out of eight identified suspects, with two still untraced. The incident sparked national outrage and protests. All previously arrested suspects named Nazrul as the rapist. Police acted on a tip that Nazrul, who had fled to Bangladesh, was returning by train. Another suspect, Milon Sarkar, was previously arrested as the gang leader, though his specific role remains unclear.

The interactive video, featuring Robert Opie from the Museum of Brands, explains why consumer buying habits change in the UK, highlighting impacts from the domestic freezer, washing powder, and cheaper imports. It also examines shifts in the ownership and ranking of major UK brands. A non-interactive version and additional resources are available for users with older browsers.

Two women in Scotland were tricked by callers pretending to work for BT, who gained remote access to their computers and stole money. The incidents occurred in Sandyhills on 15 September and in Stranraer a week later. Police warn people not to give out banking details over the phone, as legitimate companies will never ask for this information.

Duffy, 37, has signed a one-year contract to become head coach of Featherstone after leaving Swinton Lions. He will lead Featherstone in their final league game before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Duffy, previously a Scotland assistant coach and experienced player, has been praised for his work at Swinton, where he is replaced by Stuart Littler.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, a medic, and the coastguard helicopter responded to Sker Beach at 12:50 GMT on Sunday to help a rider with head injuries who was cold from lying unconscious on wet sand. She was treated and then flown to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

A UN conference in Geneva decided to dedicate part of the radio spectrum for a global satellite-based flight tracking system, improving upon the current ground radar system, which leaves 70% of airspace uncovered. This move, prompted by the disappearance of flight MH370 in 2014, will enable real-time aircraft tracking worldwide by allowing satellites to receive ADS-B transmissions from planes. Representatives from over 160 countries supported the deal at the World Radiocommunication Conference organised by the ITU, which responded quickly to calls for better tracking. The ICAO has set a November 2016 deadline for new tracking guidelines requiring planes to send their positions at least every 15 minutes.

Julian Hernandez disappeared at age five and was recently found at 18 living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez has been arrested and charged with tampering with records to obtain an Ohio driver's licence, and is held on $250,000 bail. Julian was identified after having problems applying for college, which led the FBI, Alabama police, and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children to confirm his identity. His mother has been notified. Authorities suspected the father was responsible when Julian went missing in 2002, after he said he was taking the boy to pre-school but then fled.

A fire at Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited's Duncan Street site on 2 March caused reduced train services and travel delays. Although the firm was broadly compliant with fire safety laws, the Environment Agency (EA) suspended it from accepting waste and has revoked its environmental permit following joint investigations and concerns over risks to residents, transport, and the environment. The revocation takes effect on 7 August unless appealed, after which the company must remove all waste. The cause of the fire is still unknown.

A Just Russia, a pro-Kremlin party, proposed two bills in response to the Ukraine crisis, specifically focused on Crimea, where pro-Russian sentiment is strong. The first bill would allow Russia to annex territories if local leaders request it or after a referendum, relaxing the current requirement for an international treaty. The second bill would make it easier and faster for Ukrainians, especially in Crimea, to obtain Russian passports by removing fees, residence requirements, financial proof, and the need to renounce Ukrainian citizenship. Russian officials say these changes are necessary given Ukraine's instability and frame them as support for Russian-speaking Ukrainians. Several Russian politicians and celebrities have visited Crimea to support these initiatives.

McLaren, a once-dominant Formula 1 team with 182 wins, 12 drivers’ and eight constructors’ titles, is now struggling to compete for podiums and points. Their decline began in 2013 after chassis design setbacks despite having the best engine, and current problems lie with an underperforming Honda power unit. Historically, McLaren’s cycles of triumph and decline have included eras of dominance (notably with Senna, Prost, and Honda in the late 1980s, and Hakkinen with Mercedes in the late 1990s), but they have also experienced slumps and scandals, such as disqualification and fines in 2007 and ‘lie-gate’ in 2009. Despite returning leadership from Ron Dennis and star driver Fernando Alonso’s belief in a Honda resurgence, recent seasons have brought little success. Nevertheless, team leaders remain optimistic about a return to dominance, though for now, that hope remains unfulfilled.

Thomas Baker, 44, from Everton, was shot in the head and chest outside Phoenix Gym at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on 27 January and later died in hospital. Three men from Liverpool, aged 29, 29, and 32, have been arrested and remain in custody. Police believe the shooters waited outside the gym for about an hour and are searching for a silver VW Polo that sped from the scene. Detectives are appealing for witnesses captured on CCTV near the market to come forward.

The passage discusses ways to celebrate Christmas online with a spiritual focus, without giving up technology. It highlights several digital initiatives:

1. **Everyday Church Online:** A UK-based church offering virtual Sunday services and chat rooms, attracting participants from 61 countries. Their Christmas theme uses Star Wars comparisons to explore messages of hope.
2. **Guardians of Ancora:** A free fantasy game for children aged 8–11, where players interact with Bible stories, including special Christmas quests about Jesus’s birth.
3. **Online Nativity Videos:** Popular digital retellings of the nativity story include "The Digital Story of Nativity," told through social media, and the ad "Christmas Starts with a Baby’s Giggle." The latter faced challenges with cinema advertising due to religious content.
4. **Manga Messiah:** An app and e-book version of the nativity using Japanese Manga style, available in multiple languages and distributed to refugees.
5. **Social Media Outreach:** Christian groups increasingly use platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to share spiritual messages at Christmas, aiming to inspire reflection and engagement.

The overall theme is the integration of faith and modern technology to bring spiritual content to a wider, global audience during Christmas.

An inquiry in Ebbw Vale is considering a proposal to take over 250 hectares of common land for development, with 320 hectares of replacement land offered. Experts disagree on whether the project would harm habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales questioned the value of the replacement land but did not oppose the project. Developers claim a net biodiversity gain, but the Gwent Wildlife Trust disagrees. The Planning Inspectorate will make a recommendation, and the final decision rests with Welsh government ministers.

The passage describes the reaction of Chechen Muslim clerics to a Novaya Gazeta report claiming over 100 men suspected of homosexuality were detained and tortured in Chechnya, with at least three killed. The clerics denounced the report as an insult and called for "retribution," which the newspaper interpreted as a threat to journalists. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations, claiming there are no gay people in Chechnya. The LGBT Network corroborated the abuse reports and said it is aiding victims while accusing Russian authorities of inaction and threatening to appeal to the International Criminal Court. Previous journalists investigating abuses in Chechnya have been murdered, raising concerns for press safety.

Investing Solutions and the charity Fresh Start Housing work together to house single homeless men, mainly over 35, by placing them in properties and claiming housing benefit payments, which exceed the rent paid to landlords. This model makes Investing Solutions highly profitable, with large sums claimed from councils such as Wandsworth. Though both organizations insist they act legally, critics argue the relationship is ethically questionable, with concerns over property conditions and profit motive. Fresh Start has housed hundreds of people but has not disclosed how many were placed with Investing Solutions. Both groups share the same building and founder. Oversight and property condition concerns have been raised by local authorities and homelessness advocates.

Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and Ben Gordon added 13 for Great Britain, who led most of the game before losing to the Netherlands in the final quarter of their last warm-up before Eurobasket qualifying. Coach Joe Prunty praised Gordon’s play and emphasized the need for consistent effort. Worthy De Jong led the Dutch with 18 points. GB will start their qualifying campaign in Hungary next.

Summary:
The Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) is considering a waiver request from Floyd Mayweather to use lighter 8oz gloves, instead of the standard 10oz gloves for a 154 lbs fight, for his boxing match against Conor McGregor. NAC rules generally require 10oz gloves at this weight, though waivers are possible if both fighters agree and the commission feels it is justified, prioritizing fighter safety. McGregor, making his boxing debut, submitted the necessary paperwork before the deadline, and the commission will debate the glove issue publicly on August 16. Despite criticism from boxing personalities, NAC executive director Bob Bennett approved the fight after reviewing McGregor’s fighting record and discussing with boxing experts. McGregor’s camp has also hired referee Joe Cortez for training, following NAC advice.

Fleet Street in London, once the center of British journalism, saw nearly all major newspapers based there and was renowned for its social and professional culture among journalists. Over time, shifts in technology, the rise of other media, and a pivotal move by Rupert Murdoch's papers in the 1980s led to Fleet Street's decline as a newspaper hub. The last two journalists from the Sunday Post are leaving as their London office closes, marking the end of Fleet Street’s long association with journalism. The street’s legacy is remembered for its history, lively atmosphere, and as a symbol of British press power, even as its buildings are now used for other purposes.

J.K. Rowling faced significant criticism and abuse on Twitter after donating £1 million to the campaign against Scottish independence and previously to the Labour party. She reported being called "a traitor" and blocked abusive users, particularly some SNP supporters. Despite this, she also interacted positively with other SNP supporters and noted common ground. Rowling stated she stands up to bullies online and does not feel responsible for covering up bad behavior to protect political parties. She reacted lightheartedly to a suggestion that her books be burned. The SNP won 56 out of 59 seats in Scotland in the recent election, becoming the UK's third largest party.

Children from deprived backgrounds in Scotland are twice as likely to face police action and five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision than wealthier peers for the same offenses. Poverty increases the risk of both committing and being a victim of violence, with boys generally three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts, and poorer girls twice as likely as affluent girls to be involved in violence. A history of police trouble strongly predicts young people not being in education, employment, or training by age 18. Crime and its impacts remain concentrated in Scotland’s most deprived communities, despite overall falling crime rates. The studies cited were conducted by University of Edinburgh researchers and raise concerns about persistent inequality and the role of the justice system in perpetuating disadvantage. The Scottish government notes falling national crime rates and ongoing efforts to address poverty and inequality.

Mr. Haugh, aged 25, was fatally stabbed in the Marian estate early Sunday. Robbie Walsh has been charged with assault causing serious harm and is in custody awaiting another court appearance. Two other men arrested were released pending further investigation. Police allege Mr. Walsh and two others sought out Mr. Haugh, leading to a fight involving multiple people and weapons. Mr. Haugh died in hospital from a stab wound; knives and golf clubs were recovered at the scene. The area remains tense following the incident.

Phil Flanagan, a Sinn Féin MLA, tweeted a false accusation about Tom Elliott’s conduct during his time in the UDR. The tweet was quickly deleted after Elliott was alerted by others. In court, Flanagan agreed to issue an apology, admitting his statement was untrue and unfounded. Elliott was found to have a clear record, and the judge is considering compensation. Flanagan’s insurance will not cover costs, a decision he is contesting separately. Elliott stated he felt vindicated but frustrated by the lengthy process.

Hawick Knitwear, employing over 230 staff and established in 1874, has increased weekly sweater production from 7,500 to 9,500 to meet rising demand after better than expected sales of its own brand launched in January and growth in its private label business. Recently bought by managing director Benny Hartop, the company supplies both private label and branded garments to markets in Europe, North America, and Japan. The production boost responds to increased orders domestically and internationally, and management is optimistic about the future.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright’s car outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston. Wright, 55, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and admits hitting Mrs Blackburn but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Witnesses say traffic on one side had stopped at a red light, but Wright did not stop and hit Blackburn as she escorted people across the road. Blackburn is now in residential care. The trial at Luton Crown Court is ongoing.

The passage describes a NATO anti-submarine warfare exercise called "Dynamic Mongoose," conducted in response to increased Russian submarine activity and highlighting weaknesses in British defenses. The exercise involves a German U-boat (U33) evading detection by ten NATO warships, including the USS Vicksburg, as they attempt to simulate an attack. Participants include warships, anti-submarine helicopters, and—for the first time—underwater unmanned vehicles, which provide persistent and cost-effective surveillance. The exercise underlines the challenge of detecting advanced and quiet Russian submarines, which can patrol for months undetected and are considered some of the most capable in the world. A key vulnerability identified is the UK's lack of maritime patrol aircraft, forcing reliance on allies and raising concerns about national security. The passage concludes that while the exercise aims to maintain NATO readiness, it also demonstrates some member nations, notably Britain, cannot independently conduct anti-submarine operations and must address these gaps in future defense planning.

The passage describes the worsening crisis in South Sudan, where escalating violence—often along ethnic lines—has led UN officials to warn of potential genocide and ethnic cleansing. Since July, violence spread from the capital Juba to southern Equatoria, causing 340,000 people to flee to Uganda, more than from any other country this year. Refugees report widespread killings, rape, and targeting of civilians, particularly among different ethnic groups. Uganda is providing rapid aid and land to incoming refugees, but the enormous influx—now nearly a million—has put a strain on resources. Many refugees are children who have experienced severe trauma. The international community is urged to act, as the violence has become a massacre of civilians from both sides in South Sudan.

McKenzie, 38, will fight Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight title at York Hall on 12 November. A former footballer, he turned professional as a boxer in 2013 and has eight wins and one draw in nine bouts. He is the son of ex-champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, Duke McKenzie.

The new Bridgwater Community Hospital is part of a £330 million nationwide NHS investment, with the project costing £33 million, funded by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The hospital will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and space for mobile scanners, replacing the outdated hospital built in 1813. Three of Somerset's 13 community hospitals have been replaced in the past five years, and work has begun at Musgrove Park Hospital in Taunton. The new hospital is planned for Bowers Lane, pending planning permission, with completion aimed for autumn 2014. Staff highlight the positive impact the modern facility will have on patient care and well-being.

A man was fatally shot near a black Mercedes outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, Sheffield, at about 13:35 GMT. Despite being taken to Northern General hospital, he died from a gunshot wound to the chest. The victim was reportedly attending a family celebration nearby. Armed police sealed off the area, and residents tried to help after the shooting. This incident follows several recent shootings in Sheffield, though previous ones occurred in other parts of the city.

The passage describes the activities of prominent hacker groups involved in the Russia-Ukraine conflict: the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, conduct attacks on pro-Russian targets using DDoS attacks, hack into servers, CCTV, and network printers, and disrupt rebel funding. They also claim to provide intelligence to Ukrainian security services, although officials deny using such data for military actions. Cyber Berkut, supporting the Russian side, targets Ukrainian government websites, spreads propaganda, leaks confidential documents, and claims responsibility for high-profile hacks, including disruption of elections and video billboard hijacking. Anonymous International, also known as b0ltai or Shaltay Boltay, leaks documents mainly about Russian affairs but has released material related to Ukraine; its methods and sources are unclear. The passage highlights that these groups operate independently but play significant roles in the information and cyber warfare aspects of the conflict.

Several veteran MSPs, including Tricia Marwick (presiding officer), Duncan McNeil (Labour), Alex Salmond (SNP, former first minister), and Annabel Goldie (Conservative), are standing down ahead of the 5 May election. Marwick was moved to tears during farewell speeches. Salmond reflected on Scotland's progress, highlighting the parliament's increased strength and diversity, welcomed new powers but criticized unfulfilled promises from the referendum, and emphasized the honour of serving in parliament. McNeil cautioned that Holyrood could learn from Westminster's committee system to ensure proper accountability. Goldie delivered a lighthearted speech about her parliamentary experiences.

Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care for older people in residential care in Wales by gathering experiences from pensioners, their families, care providers, staff, and public bodies. The findings will inform recommendations to improve care. The review will examine aspects like health, relationships, and care environment, aiming to highlight both good and poor care. While the review's aims are supported by Care Forum Wales, its chair, Mario Kreft, expressed disappointment that provider experts were not included on the main advisory panel, suggesting this limits sector engagement.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, increased its pre-tax profit by £800,000 to £3.5m in the year ending June 2016, despite a £1m decrease in turnover to just over £100m. The company saw growth in international sales, manufactures animal feeds, and runs 19 Country Store shops across Scotland catering to rural communities. Harbro noted ongoing challenges in agriculture and uncertainty due to Brexit, but expressed confidence in its future positioning.

A man in his 70s was found dead in a house in Little Gaddesden, and another man in his 80s was hospitalized. Police are treating the death as murder and are seeking 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker) in connection with the case, warning the public not to approach him. Police have increased local patrols and are urging anyone with information to contact them.

David Lipton, the IMF's second-in-command, warned that the global economy is weakening, citing poor Chinese trade data with exports down 25% year-over-year. The IMF is expected to lower its global growth forecast from 3.4% in April. These developments have significant negative consequences for businesses relying on China's economic growth.

The council held a meeting to address issues with a new chain ferry at Cowes, which has experienced breakdowns, grounding, suspensions, and damaged cars since its launch on 14 May. In response, the crossing will be free until 2 July to gather feedback, and an audit review has been ordered. Local businesses have suffered significant losses, leading to calls for compensation. The council is considering compensation, has resolved some technical issues, and is making modifications to prevent further vehicle damage. The problems are being attributed to the ferry being a prototype and teething problems.

A multi-vehicle crash occurred near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday, resulting in the death of a 32-year-old man. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road was closed between Thursley and Liphook until early evening for investigation.

Matching Models, a London-based agency that describes itself as an international temp agency for "beautiful and talented people," posted job adverts specifying physical requirements such as a "classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup" for a personal assistant, and a "sexy female driver." This has been widely criticized by the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) and women's equality campaigners as unlawful, demeaning, and potentially in breach of the Equality Act 2010, which prohibits discrimination in hiring. The agency defends its practices by saying client preferences are important, but legal and equality experts argue these adverts likely violate anti-discrimination laws. The agency's founder justifies such requirements as client-driven, while critics call for modern hiring standards. Matching Models claims prominent clients and international reach.

A shooting took place at a hostel of Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, where Mahesh, an office assistant, allegedly shot and killed 18-year-old Gautami and injured another student, Sirisha. Gun crime in Indian schools is rare and the motive is unclear. Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt and is in police custody until 12 April. India has strict gun laws, though some violent disputes involve firearms. A similar fatal school shooting occurred in 2007 near Delhi.

Glaad analyzed TV shows from June 2016 to May 2017 and counted 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, with transgender characters rising from seven to 16. However, over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters were killed off, including Poussey Washington (Orange is the New Black) and Bea Smith (Wentworth). The report noted a record percentage of black characters on broadcast TV, largely due to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's study was based on scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series. Glaad's president Sarah Kate Ellis acknowledged progress but said numbers are "only part of the story."

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, announced he will step down before a party meeting likely to oppose his candidacy. This follows criticism over his role as council leader in a £10.25m loan to Northampton Town FC that is now missing, with police investigating possible financial irregularities. Mackintosh denies wrongdoing, but most of his party’s local executive council supported deselecting him. The stadium project funded by the loan remains incomplete.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old policeman, shot and killed 15-year-old Jordan Edwards by firing into a car driving away from a party in Balch Springs, Dallas, after responding to reports of underage drinking. Although initial police statements claimed the car reversed towards officers, footage showed it was driving away. Oliver was fired for policy violations, charged with murder and four counts of aggravated assault, and faces up to 99 years in prison if convicted. No trial date is set. If convicted, he would be the first Dallas County officer convicted of murder since 1973. He is currently free on bail.

**Summary:**
The passage discusses Melania Trump’s decision to remain in New York with her son Barron until he finishes the school year, rather than immediately moving to the White House after Donald Trump’s election. This decision has sparked both criticism and support, with some seeing it as a reflection of responsible parenting and others questioning her First Lady role. Historically, only two other First Ladies did not reside in the White House, though several presidential families have navigated similar transitions and prioritized their children's schooling. The passage reviews the evolving public and ceremonial roles of First Ladies, noting that Melania Trump has indicated her focus is on Barron and possibly tackling cyberbullying, suggesting she may not take on a traditional, active First Lady role. There is precedent for other women, such as daughters or other relatives, taking on some First Lady responsibilities. The passage concludes that presidential families balance family life and public duties in various ways, emphasizing the importance of privacy and normalcy for their children.

A 72-year-old man was found dead at a sheltered housing complex in Inverness on 27 October. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc) has been instructed by the Crown Office to investigate the initial police response to his call. Police Scotland is cooperating with the investigation, and a report will be submitted to the Crown Office once finished.

Forecasters issued a yellow wind warning for several counties, predicting gusts up to 75mph, especially west of the mountains, with an unusual easterly direction possibly increasing impact. Disruption to road and sea travel is expected. In Anglesey, high winds brought down a tree in Menai Bridge, resulting in the closure of Telford Road for most of Monday for clean-up.

The Giants and Panthers traded goals, with the Giants leading 4-3 by the end. The teams will face each other again in a double-header, and in the standings Nottingham leads with 28 points, Sheffield Steelers have 27, and Belfast has 25.

World champion Lewis Hamilton started at the back, damaged his front wing on lap one, and made five pit stops, ultimately struggling with a damaged car and finishing behind key rivals. Sebastian Vettel finished second despite a first-lap collision with team-mate Kimi Raikkonen, who recovered to finish fifth. Daniil Kvyat and Daniel Ricciardo finished ahead of Raikkonen. The race began with multiple collisions, leading to the safety car, and was marked by risk-taking moves and post-race confrontation between Vettel and Kvyat. Nico Rosberg won the race and now holds a 36-point lead in the championship, a gap no driver has previously overturned after three consecutive wins in a season.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a prominent German footballer, publicly came out as gay to advance discussion on a topic often ignored in German football, making him the most notable player to do so. His announcement was widely praised by former teammates, football officials, players, and politicians, who called it a courageous and important step towards combating homophobia in the sport. The event is seen as a watershed moment for German football, where homosexuality remains a taboo. Supporters hope his decision will encourage more openness and acceptance of diverse sexual orientations within football.

Steve Sidwell, 34, has played 32 Championship games this season to help Brighton (the Seagulls) secure promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years. With his contract set to expire, Sidwell hopes to sign a new deal and be part of the team next season. Brighton recently confirmed promotion with a win over Wigan and have a four-point lead over Newcastle with two matches left as they aim for the league title. Sidwell joined Brighton permanently in June 2016 after a loan spell and has previous Premier League experience with several clubs. He believes his performance this season merits a contract extension and is optimistic about reaching an agreement.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1. Blackpool took the lead after 12 minutes through Jamille Matt, but Colchester equalised shortly after with a close-range goal from Kurtis Guthrie. Both teams had good chances to win, with notable saves from Blackpool’s goalkeeper Sam Slocombe. Colchester finished with 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off in injury time.

A 29-year-old player, who made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season before their relegation from League One and has previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, may debut for Colchester (the U's) in the EFL Cup against Aston Villa. Colchester began their season with a 3-1 loss to Accrington.

PC Keith Palmer’s murder in March intensified calls for a permanent UK police memorial. The UK Police Memorial Trust appealed for £1.5m towards building it at the National Memorial Arboretum, where it will honor more than 1,400 officers and staff killed in the line of duty over 250 years. The project, costing £4m, has received £1m in government funding and is expected to be completed by 2019. The memorial will include a brass screen with leaf shapes for families as personal tributes. The aim is to recognize the sacrifice and courage of British police and provide a place for national and personal remembrance.

Manchester United are 15 points clear at the top of the table with eight games remaining after a 1-0 win at Sunderland. The team has set a record with 25 wins in their first 30 matches and has earned 50 out of a possible 54 points in their last 18 games. Their next league match is a derby against Manchester City, who trail by 15 points. Manager Sir Alex Ferguson plans changes for the upcoming FA Cup replay at Chelsea due to injuries to Rafael, Anderson, and goalkeeper David De Gea sustained at Sunderland. Several players, including Wayne Rooney, may return for future matches. Ferguson praised his team’s focus, defense, and determination during a challenging second half against Sunderland.

Google chairman Mr Schmidt stated the company followed UK tax laws, paying £10m in corporate taxes from 2006-2011, and said it was the UK's responsibility to change tax rules if it desired higher corporate payments. He emphasized that companies should pay what is legally required, and Google would comply with any new laws. Meanwhile, UK officials like Margaret Hodge proposed stricter oversight of large firms' tax arrangements, and European Union leaders agreed to greater information sharing to combat tax avoidance. Schmidt argued for international tax reform and stated that tax policy should be set by politicians, not companies. Google has faced criticism for minimizing UK tax through routing sales via Ireland.

NHS Improvement is pushing for faster progress in reducing the NHS agency staff bill, which was £3.6bn last year. The goal is to cut this by £1bn by year’s end. An agency staff pay cap introduced in October has already saved £600m, limiting payments to no more than 55% above normal rates (with only senior managers exempt). Despite these savings, NHS trusts are still 10% behind their target, and it’s unclear if other staffing costs have increased. The figures don’t include NHS bank staff or staff overtime. The regulator plans to publish league tables on agency spending and collect data on the top agency earners at each trust. Some hospitals are still being charged well above the cap. NHS Improvement says more action is needed to reduce costly reliance on agency staff.

Longford Town Centre, once a symbol of Ireland's economic boom, now reflects its downturn but signs of recovery are emerging. Local trader Matt O'Brien reports improved business after diversifying his store, though trade remains below pre-crash levels. Criticism from opposition party Fianna Fáil targets the government's focus on water meter investment over broadband and the lack of industrial promotion for Longford. In response, the government points to a new Center Parcs tourism development expected to create around 1,000 jobs, though it still requires planning approval. While this may boost the area, local traders argue further support—such as removing parking charges—could enhance economic revitalization. Overall, economic conditions are improving in the midlands, but more needs to be done for sustained recovery.

The competition concludes on 29 May in the same stadium where it began. Eight teams play each other twice, with the top four advancing to the play-offs. Updates on scores, fixtures, and results are available via BBC Sport. Leading run-scorers are Warner (294), Kohli (267), and De Villiers (249). Warner and De Villiers have hit the most sixes (12 each), and the highest individual score is De Kock's 108. McClenaghan (9 wickets) leads in wickets taken. Four current or former England players—Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen—are participating with different teams. A detailed schedule of matches from 25 April to 29 May is provided, including play-offs and the final.

The number of plastic carrier bags has increased by 200 million since 2013, causing environmental problems as many are not recycled. Starting in October, people in England will have to pay 5p per bag to encourage reuse, following similar charges in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, where bag use has decreased. The aim is to reduce discarded bags and help the environment.

Strong winds in Wales caused significant disruption, including part of a school roof being ripped off in Rhosgadfan, widespread power cuts affecting hundreds of homes, delays and restrictions on trains and major bridges, and cancelled Irish Sea ferry sailings. The severe weather followed a yellow wind warning and impacted busy Christmas travel, forcing the closure of Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle. Although winds eased by Friday evening and bridge restrictions were lifted, some festive events, such as Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip, were postponed.

Michael B. Jordan expressed excitement about a new film project where he will work again with Creed director Ryan Coogler. He mentioned looking forward to working with Lupita Nyong’o, an Oscar winner, and Chadwick Boseman, who currently portrays Black Panther. Jordan’s prior roles include the Human Torch in Fantastic Four. Nyong’o appeared in Star Wars: The Force Awakens. The film, Black Panther, is set for release in February 2018.

The passage describes a restoration project at Alexandra Palace’s east wing, including refurbishing the historic theatre (founded in 1875) and BBC studios. The aim is to reopen the theatre for various performances by 2018, create public and exhibition spaces in the east court, and transform the area into a cultural destination. Funding includes £18.8m from the Heritage Lottery Fund, £6.8m from Haringey Council, and £1m to be raised by the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust, for a total project cost of £26.6m. The theatre retains much of its original decor and was originally used for multiple forms of entertainment.

James Milner, aged 30 and a former Manchester City player, earned 61 caps for England after debuting in 2009 and participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, playing only three minutes at Euro 2016. He holds the record for most England Under-21 caps (46) since 2004 and scored his single international goal during a 2014 World Cup qualifier against Moldova.

A fire completely destroyed Marcy Smith’s family home in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, after Marcy's son David noticed the flames and woke everyone up, enabling the family to escape. Sadly, their dog and cats died in the fire, which started from rubbish burned in the wood stove; the fire alarm did not go off. The family lost everything but was aided by community donations. Marcy praised David, crediting him with saving their lives.

West Ham, valued at £105m when Sullivan and Gold bought a majority stake in 2010, has recently been linked with takeover interest, including a reported £200m offer from an energy drinks giant as well as Qatari and Chinese groups. Sullivan and Gold now own over 85% of the club, with Sullivan previously indicating a minority stake might be sold to clear debts, but that overall ownership would remain in their families.

The event, unlike the Oscars, featured fan-voted awards such as best kiss and best shirtless performance. The Fault in Our Stars was the big winner, taking best movie, with Shailene Woodley also winning best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for American Sniper, and Channing Tatum won best comedic performance for 22 Jump Street. Meryl Streep won best villain for Into the Woods. Other winners included Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne. Kevin Hart received the comedic genius award, and Robert Downey Jr. was honored with the Generation Award, presented by his Avengers co-stars. The ceremony also promoted upcoming summer movies with exclusive clips.

Smith, 21, was loaned from Aberdeen (the Dons) to Dundee United in July, scoring five goals this season. He made his Aberdeen debut in 2012, with four goals in 89 appearances, and is a Scotland Under-21 international. Jack Ross, St Mirren's manager, praised Smith as a valuable signing who will strengthen their attack, ahead of their match against Falkirk.
Northumberland County Council will use Jetpatcher machines to fill 145 potholes daily over the next four months, and extra staff will repair drainage systems and clear gutters damaged by heavy rain.

In December on EnQuest’s Thistle platform off Shetland, six Wood Group contractors were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) during pipework shutdown activities. The exposure was below the threshold requiring formal reporting to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE), though EnQuest did notify HSE. The workers were not initially provided with proper PPE and learned of the radiation partway through the job, leading to concerns about their health and ongoing medical testing. EnQuest and Wood Group both stated that precautionary steps had been taken since the incident, with Wood Group temporarily removing staff from the platform for medical assessments. The union condemned the handling of the case, emphasizing the need for transparency in safety matters, while the HSE stated no investigation was necessary under current regulations.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) bought a bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari in 2007 for $650,000 from Art of the Past, whose manager later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities. The sculpture is believed to have been stolen from a temple in Tamil Nadu, India. Following a request from the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) and discussions with Singapore's National Heritage Board, ACM decided to return the sculpture. While there is no definitive proof it was stolen, the manager’s confession influenced the decision. ACM bought 30 items from this dealer, with only this sculpture suspected as stolen, and plans to seek legal compensation for fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck at a depth of 15.5km, 35km north of Lucca, Italy, with the epicentre in Garfagnana. It was felt in cities like Milan and Florence, but there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. Phone and power outages occurred locally, and schools were evacuated as a precaution. Italy has a history of deadly earthquakes, including those in L'Aquila in 2009 and the same area last May. Aftershocks followed the latest quake. In 2012, six scientists and an ex-official were convicted for giving misleading safety assurances before the 2009 L'Aquila earthquake, which led to many deaths.

Austin Grant from Sheffield was initially doubtful about growing fruit in South Yorkshire's climate, but has now successfully produced fruit, although it is not yet ripe enough to eat. He expressed great joy at this achievement.

Rockstar has delayed the release of the latest version of GTA V from 27 January to 24 March to allow extra testing and improvements. Online heists will arrive on consoles before the PC launch. New PC features include enhanced graphics, 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, triple monitor support, and published minimum specs. GTA V was initially released on 17 September 2013 and became the fastest-selling entertainment product, making $1bn in three days.

76-year-old Simpson won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize at Liverpool’s Walker Art Gallery for his work Squint (19), after being previously shortlisted in 1991 and making the longlist three other times. Squint (19), about 7ft tall, depicts a leper squint—holes in medieval churches for “undesirables” to view services. Judge Ansel Krut described the painting as extraordinary and technically subtle, though challenging to view. Simpson plans to use the prize money for art materials. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is a prestigious biennial art award in Britain, with former winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

The offices of pro-government newspapers Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, both supporters of President Erdogan's AK Party, were attacked by masked assailants early Thursday. Both buildings, located 20km apart, were damaged by gunfire but no casualties were reported. Firefighters put out a fire at Yeni Safak and police cordoned off the areas, finding numerous bullet casings. The attackers have not been identified and no group has claimed responsibility. A similar attack occurred last September on another newspaper, Hurriyet.

A 24-year-old player, previously under contract with the Stags and on loan at Crawley, will join Marcus Bignot's Mariners as his first signing on a free transfer from 1 January, after scoring three goals in 23 appearances for Crawley.

Arsène Wenger, whose club contract lasts until summer, has been linked with the England manager job, but says he is focused on his current role. Gareth Southgate, aged 46, succeeded Sam Allardyce as England manager and will have upcoming matches against Scotland and Spain to prove he deserves the job permanently. Wenger praised Southgate’s experience and opportunity. Wenger also said Arsenal’s 21-year-old defender Hector Bellerin, linked with a move to Barcelona or Manchester City, will be offered a new contract as the club sees his long-term future at Arsenal. Additionally, midfielder Aaron Ramsey will miss one or two more games due to a hamstring injury.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are jointly investigating the incident, with the company cooperating fully.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement that will resolve a dispute over underpayment of seafarers on two freight vessels, where some workers were paid less than £4 an hour. The vessels, previously run by Seatruck for Serco Northlink, will return to Serco Northlink’s direct operation next month. The new arrangement ensures all crew will receive at least minimum wage. Serco Northlink operates subsidised ferry and cargo services to the Northern Isles under a contract with the Scottish government.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital after an incident at Rockley Park in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, intervened in an argument between Mr Dickie and his mother, during which a confrontation led to Mr Dickie's death. Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault and, along with his mother Samantha, admitted to attempting to pervert the course of justice by lying to police about the events. Both will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, an influential British songwriter, died in London at 66 after a brief battle with cancer. Known for his low profile, he wrote major hits for Michael Jackson—including "Rock With You," "Off The Wall," and "Thriller"—as well as for the band Heatwave, with songs like "Boogie Nights." Temperton also wrote for other major artists, won a Grammy in 1990, and was nominated for two Oscars in 1986. Many artists and musicians paid tribute to his lasting impact on music.

Researchers including Swansea University’s Dr Neil Loader and Prof Alayne Street-Perrott, working with teams from UK and Brazilian universities, discovered over 450 ancient earthworks, or “geoglyphs,” in western Brazil’s Acre state. These structures, possibly 2,000 years old, were hidden by rainforest until recent deforestation. Their purpose is unclear but they may have been ritual gathering places rather than villages or defensive sites. Analysis of soils, plant remains, and forest burning suggests the sites were built among tall forests and challenges previous beliefs that the Amazon was untouched by humans before Europeans arrived. Instead, evidence shows ancient people managed forests, cultivating useful plants like palms, creating a “prehistoric supermarket” whose impact on biodiversity may persist today.

Nick Kyrgios, a 21-year-old Australian ranked 12th in the world, defeated world number 29 Sam Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to reach the second round. Kyrgios, coming off a win at the Japan Open, cited tiredness and travel fatigue for his subdued demeanor during the match. He also mentioned poor sleep and a difficult commute to the Qi Zhong Stadium in Shanghai. Last year at the Shanghai Masters, Kyrgios was fined for inappropriate behavior, calling the tournament a "circus."

Scientists and charities are urging the Welsh government to extend the HPV vaccination programme to protect against increasing head and neck cancers, particularly as most cases now affect younger men, many of whom are non-smokers. Currently, girls aged 12 and 13 in Wales are vaccinated to prevent cervical cancer, but campaigners want boys to be included. The government is awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making a decision. 85% of girls in Wales have already been vaccinated since the programme began in 2008.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old West Calder High School student, died from a rare blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma. He documented his treatment and experiences on a Facebook page called Jak's Journey, which gained over 28,000 likes and inspired many people due to his positive attitude. Jak briefly attended a special prom held for him before his death. He received awards for overcoming adversity, met football players and celebrities, and continued to create special memories despite his illness. After learning in January that his cancer had spread and treatment would stop, Jak and his family encouraged fundraising for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research. His story has led to further charity events in his memory.

Egypt defeated Uganda 1-0 in a match with few chances, thanks to Abdallah El Said’s late goal on 89 minutes, assisted by Mohamed Salah. Uganda had an earlier goal by Joseph Ochaya disallowed for offside. The win keeps Egypt in contention for top spot in Group D ahead of their next match against Ghana, while Uganda are eliminated from the tournament. The game was played on a poor pitch, with both teams struggling to create clear opportunities. Ghana had already secured a quarter-final place by beating Mali.

Lancashire County Council has identified land at the former Glenburn Sports College and unused Skelmersdale College’s Westbank campus for a new railway station in Skelmersdale, which has lacked a station since 1956. A comparative study favored this site over another near the Concourse shopping centre, citing its size and good access. Plans, developed with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, propose up to two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. The council will begin acquiring the necessary land, aiming to address Skelmersdale’s status as a major town without its own rail station.
Police discovered plants in an "elaborate grow house" during a Saturday morning warehouse search near Ashbourne, arresting a man in his late 40s at the scene.

A 28-year-old woman in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, was found seriously injured after being dragged by the neck through several streets; she underwent emergency surgery and was flown to a specialist clinic. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from Bad Muender, later surrendered to police. Both are German citizens of Kurdish origin. The motive for the attack is unclear, and police are seeking witnesses.

The study by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, using data from over 4,600 Australian workers, found that women are as likely as men to ask for a pay rise but are 25% less likely to receive one. The research debunked the idea that women are more reluctant to request higher pay, showing no support for the "reticent female" theory or the notion that women are hesitant due to fear of upsetting their boss or defying stereotypes. The study controlled for factors such as employment status, employer size, industry, parenthood, and qualifications. While discrimination was suggested as a reason for the disparity in outcomes, the data also showed that women and men under 40 ask for and receive pay rises at similar rates, indicating changing negotiation behaviors among younger workers.

Oxford City Council has struggled to find a new suitable burial site despite many years of searching and spending money on ground investigations; all potential council-owned sites have been rejected due to issues like ground conditions, size, water table, or legal restrictions. The two cemeteries with remaining space, Wolvercote and Botley, are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021. After that, only limited burial options will remain. The last increase in burial space was in 1932. The council is still exploring options but has run out of suitable land within Oxford.

Visitors to the Hebridean Celtic Festival in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis (19–22 July) can use an app to access online information, including videos and band interviews, by scanning signs and posters at the event. Acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. The new augmented reality feature will enhance festival-goers’ experience and also allow global audiences to interact with the festival, view updates, access interviews, buy tickets, and experience the festival atmosphere remotely.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, died after collapsing shortly after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham. Treated by veterinary staff, he was pronounced dead due to a severe pulmonary haemorrhage. The incident was described as rare and occurring without notable underlying health issues. Although Many Clouds previously experienced post-race overheating and ataxia, he had not shown these symptoms during this race. His welfare had been closely monitored, but his death is attributed to a rare and acute haemorrhage. Many Clouds was a successful racehorse, previously winning the 2015 Gold Cup trial and the 2014 Hennessy Gold Cup.

A 15-year-old girl was raped by David Ayrton (now known as Davina) in a Portsmouth garage in 2004. Ayrton, now 34 and with learning difficulties, denied the charge but was found guilty and will be sentenced on March 4. Judge Ian Pearson remanded Ayrton into custody, likely to a male prison, due to risk of self-harm and absconding. Ayrton, who has not undergone physical gender transition, disclosed the attack in 2014 to a care home worker. Protocols have been arranged for her detention, and the case was described as difficult by the judge.

Serbs lost 6-4 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio doubles. The defeat followed Djokovic’s singles loss to Juan Martin del Potro. Djokovic had also lost unexpectedly at Wimbledon to Sam Querrey, but rebounded by winning his 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

More than 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, Europe, Canada, and the US will participate in a chainsaw-only carving event in Carrbridge. They will carve logs into animals and people. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will return to defend his title and the Claymore Trophy.

Rhys Webb, out since a serious foot injury in September's World Cup warm-up, says he is close to returning and hopes to be fit before Wales’ Six Nations campaign begins in February. He is currently undergoing pre-season training and may return earlier than expected. Webb has also renewed his national dual contract with the Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down other offers to remain with his home club and pursue further opportunities with the national team.

US border agents intercepted an attempt to smuggle 58lb (26kg) of ecstasy from Canada into the US near Sumas, Washington. Two men carrying backpacks with the drugs were confronted; one fled after firing at agents and was later arrested, while the other was detained immediately. Two additional suspects—a woman and her boyfriend—were arrested for planning to transport the drugs to San Francisco, with the boyfriend allegedly offered $11,000 for the job. All three suspects in US custody face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges. The area where the incident occurred is noted for frequent smuggling activity.

Childline reported counselling over 4,500 children who experienced online abuse in the past year, almost double the number from 2011-12. The actual number affected is believed to be much higher, with some victims as young as seven. The charity highlighted the severe impact of online bullying, calling for urgent action from adults and schools to protect children. The report was released during Anti-Bullying Week, with efforts coordinated by the Anti-Bullying Alliance to address the issue. Testimonials from affected children reveal the distress caused by online bullying and the lack of understanding from some parents.

The passage describes recent tensions between Israel and the US following the US decision not to veto a UN Security Council resolution condemning Israeli settlement construction in the West Bank and East Jerusalem, which Israel considers part of its capital but Palestinians claim as their future capital. Israel was angered by the resolution and accused the US of helping draft it, an accusation the US denied. In response, Prime Minister Netanyahu took diplomatic actions against several countries. A planned vote to authorize new settlement homes in Jerusalem was postponed at Netanyahu's request to avoid further conflict before a speech by US Secretary of State John Kerry on the issue. Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas welcomed the resolution as advancing the upcoming peace conference in France.

On the eve of the Queen's 90th birthday, tributes were paid including by Prince William, who praised her as an exemplary monarch and guiding example. Celebrations included the release of stamps featuring four generations of the Royal Family, the Queen visiting Windsor's Royal Mail office, and opening a new bandstand with local schoolchildren singing "Happy Birthday". The Queen and Prince Philip will also unveil The Queen's Walkway in Windsor and light a beacon, starting a series of 900 beacons across the UK and abroad. Political leaders planned to wish her well, and US President Obama will join her for lunch at Windsor Castle. Prince William addressed criticism about his royal duties, stating he takes his responsibilities seriously but aims to balance duty with family life. The Queen, the UK’s longest-serving monarch, celebrates both her actual and official birthdays. Some, like the group Republic, criticized the BBC for excessive celebratory coverage.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2-0 in the EFL Cup. After Cheltenham's strong start, quick goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew gave West Ham control before half-time. Despite several chances for both teams, including a close volley from Harry Pell for the hosts, Cheltenham could not score. West Ham, who made seven changes after recent Premier League losses, created more opportunities and could have increased their lead, while Cheltenham, unchanged from their last game, failed to truly test West Ham's goalkeeper. This loss ended League Two's representation in the competition before the third-round draw.

Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, died in a crash on the A5 after Andreas Werner failed to see him while turning, causing the collision. Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving, was fined £1,000, and banned from driving in the UK for two years. The victim's family did not want Werner jailed, accepting it was a momentary lapse. Werner expressed remorse and had no explanation for the incident.

Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from London, was one of the most prominent British jihadists in Syria, publicly posting online as part of Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated with Islamic State and known for producing propaganda targeting British Muslims. His exact activities in Syria are unclear, but he appeared in gruesome images, including one holding a bag containing a severed head. After leaving the UK in January, Khawaja faked his own death to return unnoticed, with help from his cousin, Tahir Bhatti, who has admitted assisting an offender. Upon his return, he was arrested and is facing up to life imprisonment after admitting four offences. Khawaja is considered extremely dangerous and was held in a high-security unit while awaiting trial.

Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 games for Wrexham last season and has become Barnsley's third signing ahead of their League One play-off final. He declined a new contract with Wrexham, and Barnsley's caretaker boss praised his speed and playing style.

A large number of sealed bottles, believed to contain detergent, have washed up on Poldhu Cove and nearby beaches in Cornwall, posing a risk to wildlife. The National Trust is clearing them and advises the public to keep away. While it is suspected the bottles came from a container lost by the MV Blue Ocean during stormy weather in May, this link has not been confirmed. Conservationists are concerned about environmental harm, and authorities are monitoring the situation.

A crash occurred on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at about 14:00, resulting in several people receiving minor injuries. The road was closed, with diversions set up via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road, and Police Scotland stated that inquiries are ongoing.

Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back, made 14 appearances last season to help Bolton Wanderers secure promotion to the Championship. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances for the club. Manager Phil Parkinson praised Dervite's contributions, and Dervite has signed a new contract, joining David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan in doing so after the team's promotion.

The passage describes tensions between the Liberal Democrats and Labour in the House of Lords after initially cooperating to challenge the government on Brexit, specifically regarding EU citizens’ rights and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal. When MPs rejected their amendments, Labour accepted the Commons' decision while the Lib Dems wanted to persist, leading to accusations between the parties: Lib Dems accused Labour of conceding to the government, while Labour accused Lib Dems of giving "false hope." The passage highlights mutual criticisms, notes that the parties have a history of cooperation on various issues, and concludes that, despite ongoing opportunities to work together, recent events have created lingering tensions between them.

Defence is a low priority in the current UK election, with most political parties giving it minimal attention in their manifestos. Public interest in defence has waned, influenced by past military interventions and greater focus on issues like the economy, NHS, and immigration. The UK has been reducing its armed forces, with the Army, Navy, and Air Force all seeing significant cuts and resulting capability gaps, such as lacking Maritime Patrol Aircraft. The UK is set to fall below NATO’s 2% GDP defence spending target, with only UKIP and the DUP pledging to maintain it. Most major parties, aiming to reduce the budget deficit, are not protecting the defence budget from further cuts. The Conservatives, however, are committed to replacing Trident and increasing equipment spending, making more savings difficult. Trident’s renewal is politically divisive, with varying party positions and potential for further review or delay. The UK will soon have two large aircraft carriers, but staffing and equipping them is challenging. There are widespread concerns that further cuts will undermine the UK’s ability to maintain its traditional military influence.

Barcelona insisted they had not committed any offence in the signing of Neymar but made an additional tax payment of €13.55m to cover possible alternative interpretations of their contracts. Neymar’s transfer from Santos cost Barcelona a total of £106.8m, including fees to his parents, agents, and other expenses. Former club president Sandro Rosell resigned amid accusations of misappropriating funds and is under investigation. Authorities allege the actual cost of acquiring Neymar was higher than Barcelona originally declared. A judge ruled there is enough evidence to continue investigating the transfer, and it is unclear if Barcelona’s extra tax payment will end the case. Neymar has scored seven league goals and three Champions League goals for Barcelona this season.

Michael Luciw, 27, from Nottingham, died as a passenger in a van hit by a car driven the wrong way down a motorway by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died. Luciw’s family, grieving his loss, called for regular driving and medical tests for older or retired drivers, believing this could prevent future accidents. The current UK system only requires drivers over 70 to self-assess every three years, without a medical or driving test. The DVLA stated there is no evidence that older drivers are more likely to cause serious accidents and has no plans to change licensing rules. Age UK emphasized the importance of supporting older people to drive safely for as long as possible.

Many women have experienced serious side effects from incontinence implants, leading to concerns about their safety. Two patients and a consultant resigned from the review group over dissatisfaction with the final report, claiming it was weakened and parts were removed. An independent expert, Professor Alison Britton, will review the report process and suggest lessons for the future. The report advised against routinely offering the procedure for pelvic organ prolapse, emphasized informed patient choice, and mandated reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for a complete ban, the government will implement the recommendations but lacks the authority to ban the procedures outright, which rests with a UK regulatory body. Over 20,000 Scottish women have had these implants in 20 years, with over 400 currently pursuing legal action due to complications.

Laura Muir, 23, broke Liz McColgan’s 25-year-old British indoor 5,000m record by 14 seconds with a time of 14:49.12 at the Emirates Arena, Glasgow. McColgan expressed excitement at Muir breaking her record, though she initially questioned if all UK Athletics’ record criteria were met, noting Muir was the only 5K competitor in a mixed race.
