The passage discusses accusations of hypocrisy against comedian Russell Brand, who campaigns for economic and political revolution but lives in a luxury home. The media, including The Sun, has criticized him for speaking for the poor while being wealthy. Brand has addressed these accusations, acknowledging his wealth and past mistakes, but insists that systemic change is needed to address inequality. He argues that personal attacks on him aim to distract from real issues like economic disparity and ecological disaster. Brand maintains that acknowledging his own position doesn't invalidate the need to address inequality.

Dr. Venter is a biologist and entrepreneur known for turning human genome mapping into a competitive race, speeding up the process but facing criticism from the scientific community for his approach and self-promotion. He pioneered faster genome-sequencing techniques and left public research to found his own institutes, notably mapping the first complete genome of a free-living organism and later creating Celera Genomics to sequence the human genome commercially. After both public and private efforts published the human genome in 2001, he formed the J Craig Venter Institute, which led to the creation of "Synthia," the world's first synthetic life form—a controversial but significant scientific advance. Venter has also explored oceanic genetic diversity and believes synthetic microbes could revolutionize industries and help address environmental issues.

Researchers found that most children in England who ate school lunches tried new foods at school, with half of parents reporting that their children asked for these foods at home. A survey of about 1,000 parents showed carrots, sweetcorn, and peas were the most popular vegetables, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were least popular. The research, commissioned by England's School Food Trust, aimed to address concerns about fussy eating. School meals are now healthier and must follow nutritional guidelines. About 40% of primary school children in England eat school lunches, with a slightly higher proportion in Scotland. The survey was conducted online with parents of children aged 4-17.

Álvaro Morata, age 23, is playing for Spain at Euro 2016 and joined Juventus in 2014 from Real Madrid, with Real having an option to buy him back for up to 30 million euros. He scored 27 goals in two years at Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italia trophies, and played in back-to-back Champions League finals—scoring in the 2015 final for Juventus after previously appearing for Real in 2014. He came through Real’s youth system, debuting at 18 and scoring 10 goals for them. Morata has been linked with Arsenal and Chelsea and has scored three times for Spain in Euro 2016.

Wilson rejoined Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013, made 51 appearances in his second spell, and has been without a team since his release in May. He is 30 years old, previously played four seasons at Forest, and has also played for Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world’s third largest retailer, is exiting the US market by selling its loss-making Fresh & Easy chain to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles private equity firm. About 4,000 out of 5,000 Fresh & Easy employees will transfer to Yucaipa, while around 50 out of 200 stores will be closed. Tesco will loan Yucaipa approximately £80m as part of the deal, with total disposal costs of £150m, part of which may be recovered. Tesco may also have the option to buy back a stake if the business becomes profitable. Fresh & Easy has operated in the US since 2007 and has consistently lost money.
The individual overcame initial racial abuse, considered representing France, but ultimately aims for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

Between the late 1960s/early 1970s and the late 2000s, glacier coverage in the French Alps decreased from about 375 sq km to 275 sq km, a loss of around 26% over 40 years. This decline, documented by Marie Gardent and colleagues through satellite and manual analysis, is uneven: southern Alps massifs such as Belledonne and Ecrins saw the greatest losses, while northern areas like the Mont Blanc Massif retained more ice, partly due to higher elevation and wetter climate. These trends reflect findings across the Alps, with accelerated glacial retreat noted. The research was presented at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting.

Scotland's women's football team has won all five of their Euro qualifying matches and faces an important match against unbeaten Iceland, which could secure their first major tournament finals spot without a play-off. Star player Evans, who recently won the Bundesliga with Bayern Munich, emphasizes the emotional significance of qualifying after previous near-misses. Many squad members play for top clubs abroad, which Evans believes strengthens the national team. The outcome of the upcoming matches against Iceland will likely decide who tops the group and secures qualification.

Stuart Campbell, a blogger and pro-Scottish independence campaigner, was arrested in the west of England after a woman in south London alleged he had harassed her online over two years. Released on bail until mid-September, Campbell stated the complaint related only to tweets he insists were not threatening. Police are investigating the claims, and Campbell criticized media coverage as encouraging speculation.

Peta has proposed replacing the Jolly Fisherman mascot of Skegness with a fish mascot and the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice," aiming for a more animal-friendly image and rebranding the resort as progressive. They argue the current mascot is linked to animal cruelty. The mayor of Skegness said all suggestions are welcome but doubts there is much support for removing Jolly Fisherman, emphasizing its longstanding popularity and positive image for the town. The original mascot was created in 1908 to promote Skegness as a tourist destination, and its future will be considered by the council.

Scotland overcame an early try by Georgia’s Vasil Lobzhanidze to dominate the match, scoring multiple tries through Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, Stuart Hogg (who scored twice), and Hamish Watson. Scotland had the majority of possession and built a big lead by halftime. Despite a strong Georgian scrum and a second try by Lobzhanidze, Scotland kept control and added further scores, with Hogg finishing a notable counter-attack. Coach Vern Cotter praised his team’s ball control, pragmatic play, and continuous improvement, highlighting Greig Laidlaw’s leadership. Line-ups for both teams are provided.

Widnes defeated Castleford 38-32 after leading 14-6 at half-time and extending their lead to 38-12 in the second half. Tries from Leuluai, Ah Van, Bridge, White (2), and Mellor secured Widnes' advantage, while Castleford’s Flynn (on loan from Widnes) scored a hat-trick, with Patrick and Gale also crossing in a late rally. Despite three Castleford tries in four minutes, Widnes held on for the win. The result moved Widnes up to seventh in the league, just one point behind sixth-placed Castleford, who suffered their fourth consecutive home league defeat.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti, was released from Guantanamo after a US review panel found he was not a continuing security threat. Detained since 2002 over alleged links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban—which he denies—he challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court. Al-Odah returned to Kuwait to spend at least a year in a rehabilitation center. His release, the first since May, reduces Guantanamo’s population to 148. The facility was opened in 2002 after the 9/11 attacks, and President Obama has promised to close it.

Thousands attended Anzac Day commemorations in London, including a dawn service at Hyde Park Corner, a parade with up to 400 participants, and a wreath-laying at the Cenotaph. Anzac Day marks the anniversary of the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces during World War One, specifically the 1915 Gallipoli landings. The day is significant for Australians and New Zealanders, with services now drawing large crowds of expatriates and visitors honouring war sacrifices. The ceremonies included addresses by officials, national anthems, prayers by schoolchildren, and participation by veterans and their families. The Gallipoli campaign was one of WWI's bloodiest Allied efforts, aiming to force the Ottoman Empire out of the war.

Clarkson, aged 30, rejoined Premiership Well for a second time in July and is expected to make his St Mirren debut in the Championship against Alloa on Saturday. Last season, he scored nine goals at Dundee but has mostly been used as a substitute this term. Clarkson states he is fully fit, has maintained match fitness by playing for the U20s, and is ready to play. He has almost 400 club appearances, was capped twice for Scotland in 2008, and has previously played for Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren currently sits eighth in the Championship, seven points ahead of bottom team Alloa, and Clarkson hopes to help the team improve its position.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan. There were concerns about the workers' pension schemes under new ownership, but guarantees were given that all current agreements will be honoured. The firm's final salary pension scheme closed in 2004, but existing alternative pension arrangements will continue unaffected by the takeover. The new owner plans to restore the company’s profitability through investment, cost savings, and using spare capacity to process chicken as well as turkeys.

The council held a meeting to address issues with the new Cowes chain ferry, which has experienced several problems since its delayed launch on 14 May, including breakdowns, grounding, and suspension due to training issues. In response, the council has made the crossing free until 2 July and ordered an audit review. Local businesses have suffered significant losses, raising questions about compensation. The council acknowledged various technical and operational issues, some of which have been fixed, and discussed further measures to resolve ongoing problems.

The passage discusses the impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It highlights that fishing communities, which strongly supported leaving the EU, risk being overlooked in Brexit negotiations. The House of Lords report notes that while the industry is small economically, it is politically significant and warns that continued access to EU markets may require allowing EU boats to fish in UK waters. The report argues that parts of the EU's Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) should be retained, including science-based quotas and international cooperation. There are concerns that Brexit could result in separate regulations for different UK regions, complicating management. Despite challenges, many in the industry believe Brexit offers new opportunities for control and growth. The government states it aims to balance market access with sustainable fisheries and fair quota distribution.

Timothy Geaney admitted to offenses involving indecent images of young boys between 2004 and 2014 and was given a community payback order, put on the sex offenders register, and ordered to attend a treatment programme. Following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing, he was found unfit to teach and removed from the teaching register due to the nature and pattern of his conduct, which was deemed incompatible with the teaching profession. Geaney was also banned from reapplying to the register for two years.

A fire at Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited’s Duncan Street site on 2 March caused travel disruption and prompted the Environment Agency (EA) to suspend the company from accepting waste. Although the firm, operated by Asset and Land Group, was generally compliant with fire safety regulations, repeated site visits and concerns about potential impacts led to the EA revoking its environmental permit, effective 7 August unless appealed. The company must remove all waste, and the cause of the fire is still unknown.

Syrian Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is doing its best to meet deadlines for destroying its chemical weapons, but missed a key deadline due to attacks on weapons shipments. Mekdad blamed “terrorist groups” and ongoing war for delays, and rejected US criticism about bombing civilians, insisting the government only targets terrorists. Recent attacks in Aleppo have killed many civilians, with conflicting accounts from activists and the government about responsibility. There is also dispute over rebel control of Aleppo's prison. Syria has declared 1,300 tonnes of chemical weapons, but only about 4% has been removed so far, causing US and international concern over delays. The Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) overseeing the process says security concerns are causing slow progress, but Mekdad insists Syria will meet its obligations.

England won the Test match at Old Trafford with a day to spare, leveling the series against Pakistan. England scored 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, achieving their second biggest run-margin win over Pakistan. Joe Root, promoted to number three, was named man of the match for his 254 and unbeaten 71, as well as four catches and a wicket. England captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance, and former players noted England's dominant batting and bowling. Pakistan struggled, failing to pass 400 in either innings, with only Misbah-ul-Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the series so far. Pakistan’s captain cited poor shot selection and lack of confidence but remained hopeful. The next match is at Edgbaston after a tour game against Worcestershire.

Older People’s Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care in Wales. She is gathering evidence from pensioners and their families, as well as care providers and staff, to highlight both good and poor care and to make recommendations for improvement. The review focuses on factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. While Care Forum Wales supports the review's aims, its chair, Mario Kreft, criticized the lack of provider experts on the advisory panel, suggesting this limits sector involvement.

Paul Sheerin, a former Aberdeen (Dons) midfielder and player-manager of Arbroath since 2010, has replaced Neil Cooper at Pittodrie after being selected by Aberdeen boss Derek McInnes. Sheerin previously led Arbroath to their first national trophy in 2011 and has played for multiple Scottish clubs and in Sweden. Despite Arbroath being relegated after the 2013-14 season, Sheerin will return to Aberdeen with support from both clubs' leadership.

Swansea, following the sacking of manager Bob Bradley, will have Curtis and Paul Williams lead the next match while searching for a new permanent boss, with Paul Clement as their top target. Curtis emphasizes the urgency of avoiding relegation, noting that returning from the Championship would be challenging for Swansea. He reflects that the club has lost its former style and stability since Michael Laudrup's departure and questions whether they have successfully replaced departed players. Still, Curtis believes the squad is capable of staying in the Premier League and that new signings understand the significance of the club's journey and the importance of survival for the club and its community.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, accelerated the mapping of the human genome by making it a competitive race, sparking both vilification and admiration within the scientific community. Noted for his lack of modesty and considerable wealth, Venter's contributions notably sped up human genomics. After helping to publish the human genome, he shifted focus to creating synthetic life, leading a decade-long project at the J Craig Venter Institute that resulted in the organism "Synthia." Venter’s early life included military service in Vietnam and subsequent medical training, where he excelled in research. He pioneered faster gene sequencing methods and, after leaving the NIH due to criticism and funding issues, founded The Institute for Genomic Research. In 1995, he unveiled the first complete genome of a free-living organism and, in 1998, founded Celera Genomics to sequence the human genome faster than the public project. Despite criticism over his approach to open science, Venter achieved financial independence, enabling further ambitious projects, including oceanic genome sampling. His synthetic life work, though controversial, aims to revolutionize industry and address environmental challenges.

The passage discusses a Sutton Trust report warning that many apprenticeships in England are low quality and too short compared to those in countries like Germany, where apprenticeship systems are more robust and respected. The report highlights that most apprenticeships in England are below A-level standard (level three), with few opportunities for young people and many aimed at older workers already employed. It notes the system is complex, with too many qualifications, and apprenticeships are offered by far fewer employers than in Germany. The Sutton Trust calls for a major expansion, prioritizing at least 300,000 high-quality level three apprenticeships lasting three years, and restricting shorter, lower-level courses. Stakeholders agree on the need for improvement but suggest some lower-level apprenticeships are still valued. The government says reforms are underway to improve standards.

Sarah Storey, Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals across cycling and swimming, finished over two minutes ahead of Anna Harkowska in Nottwil, Switzerland. At 37, she is aiming for her 17th world title in the upcoming road race and targeting further Paralympic success in Rio 2016. Storey began her career in swimming, switched to cycling in 2005, and has won 21 world titles and four golds at the 2012 London Paralympics.

Hereford United was expelled from the Football Conference after failing to meet multiple extended deadlines to pay off £148,000 owed to football creditors. Despite last-day efforts on the field and fans’ fundraising, the club's total debts reached about £225,000, including more than £70,000 owed in taxes. Attempts by the Hereford United Supporters' Trust to buy and save the club were unsuccessful, and new owner Tommy Agombar could not provide the required financial assurances. As a result, Chester was reinstated to the Conference Premier, and Hereford’s players and supporters were left disappointed. Declining attendances since their 2012 relegation worsened Hereford’s financial problems.

James Milner, aged 30, won 61 caps for England’s senior football team after debuting in 2009, participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, and scored one international goal against Moldova in a 2014 World Cup qualifier. He also holds the record for most England Under-21 caps with 46. Milner announced his decision to step back from international duty, wishing the team future success.

Christopher Hogwood died at his home in Cambridge after several months of illness. He was a major figure in the early-music movement, founding the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973 and directing it for about 30 years, making over 200 recordings, including the first complete Mozart symphonies on period instruments and an acclaimed version of Handel's Messiah. Hogwood also worked with leading orchestras, held academic and directorial roles, and was known for his generosity, musicianship, and impact as a mentor. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service planned later. Colleagues and students praised his musical insight and character.

A boy from Northern Ireland was removed from mainstream school due to difficulties coping and is awaiting a place at a special school, as all in the area are currently full. His mother had to leave her job to care for him, and the family is concerned about isolation and the wider issue of overcapacity in special schools. The Education Authority stated they cannot comment on individual cases but are reviewing special school needs to improve placement availability in Northern Ireland.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is bidding to take over the Newport Gwent Dragons and wants to establish Rodney Parade as a rugby venue. Newport County, who have a lease with fixture priority until 2023 while in the Football League, expect their contract to be honored amid these changes. A shareholder vote on the Dragons' takeover is scheduled for 9 May, and both Newport County and Newport Squash Club are said to be protected by existing agreements. The WRU plans to install an artificial surface, which conflicts with Football League regulations. On the field, Newport County are fighting to avoid relegation from League Two, needing a win and a Hartlepool loss to secure survival, as dropping to the National League would be a major setback for the club and city.

Summary:
The country was recently declared free of a virus that killed nearly 4,000 people over the past 18 months. The passage follows a man who was kidnapped by RUF rebels at 15 during the civil war, forced into violence and drug use, but later escaped to Freetown. After being jailed, he met a preacher, Richard Cole, who inspired him to pursue education and contribute positively to society. During the Ebola crisis in Sierra Leone in 2014, he and others set up a clinic, educated over 10,000 people, supported thousands with food, and established a treatment unit with community help, saving many lives. Despite his troubling past, he is now committed to investing in youth and believes in their role in building a better future. Ebola deaths included 3,955 in Sierra Leone, with over 11,000 deaths globally.

A collection of about 80,000 Wedgwood art works, documents, and artifacts was at risk of being auctioned to pay the pottery firm's pension debt. A public fundraising campaign quickly met its target, allowing the collection to remain at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire. The Art Fund will transfer the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, which will then loan it back to the Wedgwood Museum. Administrators and campaigners celebrated saving the collection from being sold and dispersed, preserving its cultural importance for Britain and Staffordshire.

Dan Groves stated that the specifics of a potential deal for Wright to buy 20% of Billericay Town have not been made public. The Sun reported that Wright, who is 30 and a former non-league footballer and reality TV runner-up, would become a club director. Billericay are currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points off the play-offs. Recently, multi-millionaire Glenn Tamplin took over the club and is investing £10,000 a week. The club also recently signed ex-England international Paul Konchesky.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1. Blackpool took the lead after 12 minutes with a goal from Jamille Matt, but Colchester equalised soon after through Kurtis Guthrie. Both teams missed further chances, with Blackpool's goalkeeper Sam Slocombe making several key saves. Colchester finished the match with 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle in injury time.

The disused Fawley power station chimney is planned to become the tallest attraction south of London’s Shard and will be the centerpiece of a £1bn "merchant city" development by Fawley Waterside, including a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The power station, commissioned in 1971 and closed in 2013 after powering one million homes, was sold to developers in 2016. The development aims to repurpose the iconic 198-metre chimney rather than demolish it, with building possibly starting in 2018 pending planning permission.

At the Hong Kong championships, 23-year-old Latham won bronze in his event, securing Great Britain's second medal after Elinor Barker's silver in the women's scratch race. Latham chased down the leaders, finishing behind Teklinski of Poland (gold) and Liss of Germany (silver). In team events, GB's men's pursuit squad lost the bronze to Italy, while the women's team finished fifth in the heats and did not medal. In other results, Joe Truman was eliminated in the men's keirin semi-final, and Katy Marchant, the only British female sprinter, was knocked out in the first round of the women's sprint. Olympic and expert commentators praised Latham's performance and noted the promise shown by the young women's team pursuit squad, looking ahead to future improvement.

Ross Kemp will make a brief return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell for Barbara Windsor’s final episodes, in which her character, Peggy, will die of cancer. Kemp’s return will reunite the Mitchell brothers for their mother’s farewell. Peggy reappeared on the show to reveal her cancer had returned, and the storyline will culminate in emotional scenes in the spring. Kemp, who played Grant from 1990-1999 and again in 2005-2006, agreed to return due to his close friendship with Windsor and the significance of the storyline. The show's producers highlight the emotional impact of the Mitchell brothers being reunited to say goodbye to their mother.

Sadio Mane scored two quick goals as Spurs were defeated at Anfield, leaving manager Pochettino frustrated by his team's lack of desire and readiness to fight for the Premier League. Spurs have struggled away from home, with only two away wins since September and just one win in their last 17 away games against top-six sides. If Chelsea win their next match, they can extend their lead further. Commentators noted Spurs’ poor defensive performance and a need to rethink their tactics, especially in away games, to remain competitive.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governorships in Nigeria's recent elections, marking the largest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. The PDP, which also lost the presidency for the first time, retained only eight governorships, mainly in the south-east, and lost control in several key northern states. The APC now controls most northern states and Lagos, but did not win any of the five oil-producing states, a challenge for President-elect Muhammadu Buhari. The elections were generally more peaceful than past ones, although some violence occurred, especially in southern states. The PDP is expected to enter a period of rebuilding after losing significant influence, due to defections, corruption allegations, and perceived failure to address security issues.

Visitors to the Hebridean Celtic Festival in Stornoway (19–22 July) can use an app to access online information—including videos and band interviews—by interacting with signs and posters at the event. Acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, and others. The augmented reality feature allows both attendees and people worldwide to access festival information, buy tickets, and experience the atmosphere.

Summary:  
Several Birmingham academies, including Park View, Nansen Primary, Oldknow Academy, and Golden Hillock School, were rated inadequate by Ofsted amid concerns of a hardline Muslim takeover, known as the "Trojan Horse" scandal. The Department for Education has moved to terminate the funding agreements of Park View and Nansen, and warned Oldknow and Golden Hillock they could also lose funding if serious concerns—such as discriminatory practices and lack of balanced curriculum—are not addressed by 4 July. Ofsted reported a culture of fear and attempts to impose a narrow, faith-based ideology in some schools. School trusts and some parents dispute Ofsted's findings, claiming bias, while local authorities and government officials are working to install temporary governing boards and improve failing schools.

Vincent Barker (Vinnie) died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. Eye specialist Honey Rose is on trial at Ipswich Crown Court for gross negligence manslaughter, accused of failing to detect Vinnie’s swollen optic discs and not referring him for further investigation. The prosecution argues this failure was criminally below expected standards and led to Vinnie’s preventable death. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg was found guilty at Dundee Sheriff Court of coercing a woman into sexual activity and filming her with a man he arranged through an adult website. He also sent a sexually explicit video to the victim's sister on Christmas Day and was convicted of causing her sister and father to view sexual images and behaving abusively. The case was sent to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to its serious nature. Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register, assessed as moderately at risk of re-offending, and the judge emphasized the need for a sentence reflecting society's abhorrence of his actions.

Afghanistan defeated Ireland by six wickets in a T20 match at Greater Noida. Ireland scored 165-5, with Stuart Thompson making 56, Gary Wilson 41 not out, and captain William Porterfield 39. Afghanistan chased the target, reaching 171-4, thanks to Samiullah Shenwari’s 56 and Mohammad Shahzad’s 47, with two overs remaining. Amir Hamza was the only bowler to take more than one wicket. Ireland missed paceman Boyd Rankin due to injury. The teams will play again at the same venue on Friday.

Barcelona insisted they committed no offence in signing Neymar and stated their tax payments were correct. They paid £48.6m to Santos for Neymar, with £34m going to his parents; the total cost (including fees, wages, and tax) could reach £106.8m. There have been allegations and an ongoing investigation into whether the transfer involved misappropriated money, leading to the resignation of president Sandro Rosell, who denies wrongdoing. Barcelona made an extra tax declaration of 13.6m euros as a precaution but continued to deny any tax crime. Neymar has scored seven league goals and three in the Champions League for Barcelona that season.

David Miller and Hannah Witheridge were found dead on a Koh Tao beach on 15 September. UK police worked with Thai police, who are holding two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, accused of rape and murder after allegedly confessing, although they later reportedly withdrew these confessions. UK detectives have finished their review in Thailand and will update the victims’ families. The UK raised concerns with Thai authorities about the investigation methods, especially regarding DNA evidence and suspects’ treatment. Miller died from drowning and head injury; Witheridge died from head wounds. Thai police say DNA found on Witheridge matches the suspects.

The Scots have won all five of their qualifiers so far and are set to play Iceland at Falkirk Stadium, with a win likely to secure their place in the finals. Having narrowly missed out on previous major tournaments, striker Jane Ross Evans expresses the importance of not missing this chance. Both Scotland and undefeated Iceland are strong in the group, and their matches will likely decide who comes top. Many Scottish players, including Evans, now play abroad in top leagues, which is seen as benefiting the national team. Evans recently won the Bundesliga with Bayern Munich and believes international experience strengthens Scotland as they aim for their first major tournament finals.

The passage discusses Apple’s response to the theft and online posting of celebrities’ photos stolen from iCloud using third-party software. Apple is strengthening iCloud security by extending two-step verification to cover the back-up service, which previously allowed hackers to bypass protections using tools like Elcomsoft’s Phone Password Breaker. With this change, users logging in from new devices must enter a verification code in addition to their password, and will be notified by email when a backup is being downloaded. However, two-step verification remains optional, not default, and some experts argue it should be mandatory. While the changes block the hacking method used in the leaks, concerns are raised about the difficulty and risks of losing the recovery key. Apple says it will encourage more users to turn on two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords, with company leadership emphasizing the need for increased public awareness.

UKIP won May's election, spending £2,956,737, while the Conservatives spent £2,980,815, the Lib Dems £1,580,575 (losing all but one MEP), Labour £1,027,339, and the Greens £534,249. Spending per vote was 68p (UKIP), 79p (Conservatives), £1.45 (Lib Dems), 26p (Labour), and 43p (Greens). Including the SNP (£267,372), the six top parties spent £9,347,087 in total. Except Labour, all spent more than in 2009.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has left Barrow by mutual consent to join a National League rival and may play against his former club soon. Striker Keating, 21, joins the Gulls on recommendation, pending international clearance, having previously played in Ireland. Gulls boss Nicholson praises both players for their potential and leadership. The Gulls are four points above relegation, with only one win in six games.

Many Clouds, a 10-year-old Irish-bred racehorse, collapsed and died from a severe pulmonary haemorrhage after narrowly winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham. Despite having a history of post-race overheating and ataxia, he showed no such symptoms before his death and had no significant underlying health issues. The British Horseracing Authority emphasized that such fatalities are rare and committed to investigating their causes. Many Clouds was previously successful in major races and was highly regarded by his trainer.

Several prominent MSPs, including Tricia Marwick, Duncan McNeil, Alex Salmond, and Annabel Goldie, are stepping down ahead of the 5 May election. Presiding officer Marwick was emotional as McNeil and Salmond gave their farewell speeches. Salmond, former first minister, reflected on Scotland's diversity and parliamentary progress, but criticized the Scotland Bill for not meeting referendum promises. McNeil, a long-serving Labour MSP, emphasized the need for Holyrood to learn from Westminster's committee system and to ensure accountability. Annabel Goldie also delivered a light-hearted farewell. Marwick commended Salmond’s contributions to parliament and Scotland.

The passage announces the main cast and crew of the upcoming live-action "Beauty and the Beast" film, set for US release on 17 March 2017. Emma Watson stars as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, Kevin Kline as Maurice, and Josh Gad as LeFou. Mrs Potts will be played by a new star, succeeding Angela Lansbury from the 1991 animated version. Bill Condon will direct the film, with filming starting in May at Shepperton Studios.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce its decisions regarding possible charges related to the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster, in which 96 football fans died, during a meeting with victims' families. Evidence on 23 suspects has been considered, with 15 cases relating to the disaster's causes and eight about police conduct afterwards. The meeting will be led by Sue Hemming, CPS special crime division head. Families, represented by Margaret Aspinall, hope for accountability after a long wait, following inquests that ruled the deaths unlawful.

Chelmsford Prison has reported an increase in incidents of packages, often containing contraband like mobile phones and synthetic cannabis, being thrown over its walls. Residents and a former inmate describe the problem as persistent, with some alleging the use of drones, although the Ministry of Justice says there is no evidence of drone use at this site. The Ministry states that staff are working hard to stop contraband but acknowledges more needs to be done, and laws now allow for up to two years in jail for smuggling packages over prison walls. Residents have been invited to a meeting to discuss the issue.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by Brian Wright’s car outside a school in Kempston. Wright, 55, claims he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see the red traffic light or Blackburn, who was helping children cross the road. He admits to hitting her but denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Blackburn is now in residential care, and Wright expressed remorse in court. The trial is ongoing.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle-distance runner and veterinary medicine student, will miss next year’s Commonwealth Games in Australia due to university exams in May and her commitment to completing her final year of studies. Although disappointed, she prioritizes her degree but remains optimistic about her athletic future, targeting at least two or three more Olympics and potentially the World Indoor Championships in March. Muir recently set a new personal best in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, finishing sixth, and expressed pride in her performance despite tough competition.

Trevor Deely, 22, went missing after a Christmas party in Dublin in December 2000. Gardaí are currently searching a three-acre site in Chapelizod, involving excavations expected to take weeks. A recent review of the case used enhanced CCTV footage showing Deely talking to and later being followed by an unidentified man in black, whom detectives are appealing to come forward. The man has not yet been identified.

Juan Martin Del Potro, ranked 165th after a long injury break, defeated Swiss player Stan Wawrinka 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-2), 6-3, marking his first Grand Slam since 2014. Del Potro, a former US Open champion, overcame early struggles and multiple wrist surgeries to secure victory and will next face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. In other Wimbledon action, Nick Kyrgios came from behind to beat Dustin Brown in five sets, setting up a third-round match with Feliciano Lopez, who also won after trailing by two sets. Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga both claimed straightforward wins in their respective matches.

Tunisia risked expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after a dispute with Caf over refereeing decisions during the 2015 tournament, but avoided disqualification by apologising. Morocco was initially banned from the 2017 qualifying draw due to refusing to host the 2015 tournament over Ebola fears, but this ban and a large fine were overturned and reduced by the Court of Arbitration for Sport. Both Tunisia and Morocco are cleared to participate in the 2017 tournament, with Tunisia set to play in Group A and Morocco in Group F. If Tunisia qualifies, it will be their thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup appearance.

McLaren, once one of Formula 1’s most successful teams with 182 wins, 12 drivers’ titles, and 8 constructors’ championships, has fallen into decline, now celebrating minor achievements like strong grid positions and points. Their slump began in 2013, first through chassis issues despite a good engine, and now due to problems with the underperforming Honda power unit, despite still having top drivers like Fernando Alonso. Historically, McLaren had cycles of dominance, notably during the Honda and Mercedes eras, but have also faced scandals and technical challenges. Leadership changes, particularly Ron Dennis’ return, have yet to reverse their fortunes. The team remains optimistic about a revival, believing they are close to regaining competitiveness, but for now, their reputation and the hopes of their champions rest on faith in future improvement.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven early on 6 October 2014. Police found people still present and evidence the bar served alcohol past legal hours. The bar’s license holder, Colleen O'Neill, and James Thomas were charged with allowing alcohol consumption outside permitted times. The judge described Ms O'Neill’s record as appalling, ordered the bar closed for three months, fined her £3,000, and fined Mr Thomas £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most three-pointers in a season by hitting eight threes and scoring 45 points to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 comeback victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry also had nine assists, and Klay Thompson scored 26 points. For Portland, LaMarcus Aldridge had 27 points and Damian Lillard added 20. In another game, Pau Gasol recorded 16 points and 15 rebounds as the Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78, moving back to the No. 3 spot in the Eastern Conference. Hassan Whiteside led Miami with 19 points and 16 rebounds, while Dwyane Wade struggled with just nine points on 4-of-20 shooting.

YouTube star Bas van Velzen, known for his free-kick skills, visited Liverpool’s Melwood training ground and surprised players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic. The players were told van Velzen was a competition winner there for a free-kick masterclass, but they soon realized he was highly skilled as he impressed them with his abilities. Van Velzen, who became famous for his free-kick videos, enjoyed meeting the players and entertaining them by initially pretending to be less skilled. The event included memorable moments such as van Velzen scoring impressive goals and sharing a light-hearted experience with the Liverpool players.

Women with a BRCA1 gene mutation, like Angelina Jolie, can significantly reduce their risk of death after being diagnosed with breast cancer by having their ovaries removed (oophorectomy). A Canadian study of 676 breast cancer patients with BRCA mutations found that oophorectomy led to a 62% decrease in breast cancer deaths for BRCA1 carriers, but not for those with BRCA2 mutations. The procedure, particularly when done within two years of diagnosis, results in substantial survival benefits, with a 73% reduction in death among early BRCA1 carriers. Oophorectomy also lowers death from all causes by 65%. These findings suggest oophorectomy should be discussed as a treatment option for BRCA mutation carriers with early-stage breast cancer. The study notes that further research is needed, especially for BRCA2 carriers. Genetic testing can identify women at higher risk, and BRCA mutations are especially prevalent among Ashkenazi Jewish women.

A married couple, Derek Lowe (38) and Tina Lowe (33), were struck and killed by an Amtrak train on Easter morning in Durham, North Carolina, after lingering on the tracks. The accident occurred shortly before 10 am as train no. 80, the Carolinian, was traveling from Charlotte to New York City. None of the 166 train passengers were injured, though one person fell ill during the delay. The train resumed its route after a delay of nearly three hours. The couple may have lived in a homeless camp.

Carlos Toro, 66, worked for 27 years as an undercover DEA informant after fleeing Colombia, where he was a mid-level member of the Medellin cartel. His information helped prosecute major figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. Despite being promised U.S. citizenship for his service, Toro was never granted it and now faces deportation after retiring due to health issues. He is living in the U.S. illegally, unable to collect benefits, and fears for his life if returned to Colombia. The DEA has not helped him with citizenship, and he remains in legal limbo, prepared to go into hiding if necessary.

A U.S. regulatory body is investigating whether Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. is acting illegally by selling '.sucks' domain names at high prices, targeting celebrities like Kevin Spacey and companies trying to protect their reputations. The domains, which have been purchased by major brands such as YouTube, Bing, Visa, and Yahoo, cost around $2,499 a year and have been described by an advisory industry panel as a "shakedown scheme." ICANN, the body that approved the domain, is reconsidering after complaints and has contacted U.S. and Canadian regulators to determine if action should be taken against Vox Populi.

A baby boy’s body was found in a pond in Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk, in 1988, wrapped in a blanket in a Sainsbury’s bag. Despite initial investigations, the mother was not identified at the time, and villagers paid for the baby's burial at St Peter’s church. In 2014, police exhumed the body as part of a case review and, using DNA evidence, traced the mother 27 years later. She admitted the baby was stillborn, her pregnancy had been secret, and she placed the body in the pond. She was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but not charged after explaining the circumstances; police ruled out foul play. The baby, named Peter after the church, was reburied with a new headstone, and police now consider the case solved.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, has been ordered to pay compensation after unlawfully imprisoning passenger Kristopher Hicks, who suffered severe brain injuries when he jumped out of Young's moving taxi. The incident occurred in Bath in 2010 when Young, wrongly suspecting Hicks of intending not to pay the fare, drove him back to the taxi rank rather than releasing him. Hicks jumped from the car at over 20mph, resulting in brain injuries, epilepsy, and the need for lifelong care. The High Court ruled in favor of Hicks, awarding damages with a 50% reduction due to Hicks' actions, and a further £250 for unlawful imprisonment. The exact compensation amount, likely in the hundreds of thousands of pounds, will be determined at a later hearing, with both parties allowed to appeal.

Several tornadoes and severe storms occurred Wednesday night in Kansas, with tornado sirens sounding and twisters reported near Goddard and Aetna. While a tornado missed Wichita, other areas remained at risk. Nighttime tornadoes were highlighted as particularly dangerous. Missouri was also affected, with possible tornado damage, flooding, and large hail reported in Potosi and nearby towns. More storms are predicted for Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida are set to fight in New Jersey, with both fighters eyeing a potential title shot. Rockhold, who is on a three-fight win streak since losing to Vitor Belfort, plans to be aggressive and use his well-rounded skills to dominate Machida, whom he respects but believes has limited chances of winning, especially on the ground. Machida, coming off a win as well, is confident in his own strategy and preparation, believing he can exploit weaknesses in Rockhold and earn a title shot with a victory. Both fighters express mutual respect but are determined to impose their styles and win.

A light general aviation aircraft was filmed in Fort Pierce, Florida, landing without deploying its landing gear, skidding along the runway on its belly and damaging its propellers. Despite this, the pilot managed to re-engage the engines and take off again, later flying 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landing safely. The 85-year-old pilot, Chris Georgaklis, has flown for nearly 50 years and was accompanied by his dog. The incident, attributed most commonly to pilot error or mechanical fault, is being investigated by the FAA.

Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini admitted disappointment in midfielder Yaya Toure's performance this season but pledged to support him until the end of the campaign. City are considering selling Toure in the summer to refresh their ageing squad, though Toure is determined to stay. City have struggled recently, dropping points and risking their top-four position. Captain Vincent Kompany is out injured, and goalkeeper Joe Hart accepted that players share responsibility for the team's underperformance, maintaining that Pellegrini still has the squad’s support. Meanwhile, West Ham’s Sam Allardyce warned Aaron Cresswell about moving to a bigger club like City or Chelsea, referencing other English players who struggled for game time after such moves.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the “Godfather of Uxbridge,” will be allowed to remain in the UK after his Italian prison sentence was dropped. Rancadore, who has lived in Britain for over 20 years under an assumed name, was convicted in Italy in 1999 for mafia association and given a seven-year sentence. He lost his battle against extradition in February, but because his case expired last October under Italian law, his sentence can no longer be enforced and the European arrest warrant is being withdrawn. The conviction remains, but Italian law states that sentences are extinguished if more than twice the penalty period has passed. The case still awaits a hearing at the Italian supreme court, but Rancadore is expected to be discharged shortly. The handling of the case, including delays and administrative errors by UK and Italian authorities, led to criticism over the waste of time and resources. Rancadore’s neighbors describe him as quiet, and his solicitor expressed relief that he can live in peace with his family in England. The passage also gives background on the Sicilian mafia and its structure.

Mr Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls and ridden by AP McCoy in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown, is one of three 7-2 co-favourites in a seven-runner field, along with Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre. This will be McCoy’s final Grade One race before retirement, and his full schedule for his last day is not yet decided. McCoy previously announced his retirement after winning on Mr Mole at Newbury in February. Other runners include Somersby.

Virginia Trimble Ritter’s daughter, Marcia, was raped and murdered by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Marcia’s body was found 33 days after her disappearance, and for decades, Ritter avoided seeing the crime scene photos, following her then-husband’s advice. Barrett was not charged until 2006 when DNA evidence linked him to the crime, and in 2009, he was convicted of second-degree murder and sentenced to 44 years in prison. Last year, Ritter finally viewed the crime scene photos, experienced renewed horror and anger, and expressed a desire for revenge. The case was one of Nashville’s most infamous unsolved murders for 33 years.

Rory McIlroy believes it is "unthinkable" that he will not eventually win the Masters to complete the career grand slam, joining just five other players who have achieved this. He views his 2011 Masters collapse as the most important day of his career because it taught him valuable lessons, which helped him later win four majors. McIlroy only has one top-10 finish at the Masters so far but feels confident Augusta is a course he can win on, potentially multiple times. Despite past personal and legal distractions, McIlroy uses golf as his sanctuary and is focused on winning the green jacket to fulfill his career-long goal.

The passage summarizes trending stories from the week, including: four rainbows in New York photographed by Amanda Curtis; a crackdown in rural China on hiring exotic dancers for wakes; Robert Downey Jr. getting agitated in an interview; the “#kyliejennerchallenge” lip plumping trend; 102-year-old Alice Barker revisiting her past with filmmakers; controversy over a “prom-posal” referencing bombs; Ewan McGregor joining the “Beauty and the Beast” cast; Johnny Depp’s transformation in the "Black Mass" trailer; a pregnancy announcement inspired by "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air"; and a military dad photobombing his son. All these stories were popular online that week.

Hundreds of children in England were hospitalised last year due to brain damage from foetal alcohol syndrome, with 272 cases officially recorded, though experts warn actual numbers may be higher. Research suggests at least 1 in 100 UK babies could suffer learning, behavioural, or physical problems from alcohol exposure in the womb—about 7,500 cases annually. The condition is lifelong, under-diagnosed, and includes a range of health issues. Current government advice is to limit alcohol during pregnancy, but some experts call for a recommendation of complete abstinence.

An axe-wielding robber, Shaun Andrew McKerry, was jailed for six years after attempting to rob the Shildon Post Office and Stores in County Durham. The robbery on March 15 was foiled when shopkeeper Sab Dhillon tackled McKerry and Dhillon’s wife, Sam, hit him with a baseball bat, helping to disarm him. McKerry, a 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender known as “boomerang boy” for repeatedly returning home after crimes, had a long criminal history beginning at age 12. He pleaded guilty to attempted robbery and was arrested at the scene by police.

Four Royal Navy sailors—Joshua Finbow, Simon Radford, Craig Stoner, and Darren Smalley—have been charged with the gang rape of a young woman at a party in Canadian military barracks in Nova Scotia. They must remain in Nova Scotia, living on the Stadacona naval base in Halifax and surrendering their passports as part of unusual bail conditions. They will keep working for the Royal Navy and are forbidden from contacting the victim or witnesses. The alleged incident took place after a hockey game on April 10, and the sailors face charges that carry up to 14 years in prison. The investigation is ongoing.

Valerie Jackson’s four-year-old son, RJ, suffers from Netherton’s syndrome, an extremely rare congenital skin disease that makes his skin appear red, scalded, and scaly. Misunderstanding his condition, a member of the public falsely accused Valerie of child abuse, resulting in armed police confronting her while shopping. Valerie and her family regularly coat RJ in creams to manage his symptoms and face frequent public misunderstanding, taunts, and exclusion from places like play centers. Netherton’s syndrome is difficult to diagnose, has no cure, and requires ongoing skin care. Valerie discovered her son's condition through an online support group after struggling for answers from doctors. She emphasizes the ignorance and stigma they encounter, but remains devoted to caring for her son and raising awareness about his rare illness.

Campaigners successfully pushed for the removal of controversial "Are you beach body ready?" Protein World adverts from the London Underground, after widespread backlash from feminists and body image advocates. The adverts, featuring a bikini-clad model, sparked over 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority and a Change.org petition with 50,000 signatures, claiming the ads promoted unrealistic and unhealthy body standards. Some posters were defaced in protest, and a rally was organized in Hyde Park. Protein World strongly defended the campaign on social media, at times responding harshly to critics. Despite threats and public debate—including a bomb threat now under police investigation—the company stood by its campaign, claiming it was aimed at promoting fitness. The ASA is assessing the complaints, while sales of protein powders in the UK continue to rise. The ads were removed as their paid period ended, but Transport for London noted public reaction will inform future decisions on similar advertising.

Rail companies are facing criticism for planning steep fare increases—up to 87%—shortly after the general election, despite both major political parties pledging to freeze or cap train prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has written to First Great Western (FGW) asking them to urgently review their decision to nearly double some fares on the London-to-Cotswolds route, which passes through his constituency. For example, passengers traveling from Charlbury to London could see their off-peak return fare rise from £33.30 to £62.40. Other rail firms, including London Midlands and Virgin, are also raising certain fares by over 20%. Rail companies defend the increases by saying they bring fares in line with other routes and offer cheaper advance ticket options, but the hikes have drawn public anger and political intervention.

Former soldier John Young, 66, was left permanently blind in one eye after being hit in the face with a brick thrown through his front door by vandals in Oldham, Greater Manchester. The incident occurred around 11 pm on April 18, just three weeks after he married his wife, Elaine, 54. The couple were writing wedding thank you cards when youths began throwing stones and bricks at their home; John was struck after opening the door to confront them. Despite emergency surgery, doctors could not save his eyesight. Police have launched an investigation but have found no clear motive, suggesting it may have been a case of reckless behavior. The attack has left the couple feeling unsafe and planning to move away. Police urge anyone with information to contact them.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, who missed the 2014 season due to injuries from a car accident that also resulted in his father's death, has made a successful playing comeback after ankle surgery and has signed a new one-year contract extension to stay with Derbyshire until the end of 2016. Derbyshire’s elite performance director praised Poynton’s resilience and hard work in returning to the team.

Five-year-old Harley Renshaw from Stretford was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer, which had spread to his kidney, lungs, neck, and bones. To help him cope with treatment, Harley decorated his radiotherapy mask as a Ninja Turtle, which gave him strength and caught the attention of hospital staff and the media. He underwent intensive chemotherapy, surgery, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy, eventually being declared cancer-free by doctors after a year of treatment. Harley's bravery was recognized with awards, and his story was widely shared, including support from the TV channel Nickelodeon. Neuroblastoma affects fewer than 100 children annually in the UK, most under five, and is the second most common solid childhood tumor. Symptoms and treatment vary depending on location and spread, with options including surgery, chemotherapy, antibody treatment, and radiotherapy.

Aston Villa manager Tim Sherwood has advised 19-year-old Jack Grealish to focus on establishing himself at his club rather than worrying about his international future, as Grealish is being pursued by both the Republic of Ireland and England. Sherwood, impressed by Grealish’s recent performances, especially in the FA Cup semi-final win over Liverpool, believes Grealish should secure a regular place in the Villa first team before choosing his international allegiance. Grealish’s father agrees that club football should be the priority for now, and acknowledges the upcoming decision between playing for Ireland or England will be difficult and is ultimately up to Jack.

Private jet landing fees at airports can vary dramatically, with some unexpected hubs charging the highest rates, particularly in Japan, where Haneda, Narita, and Kansai airports are the top three most expensive. Landing a 767-400 can cost from about £2,530 ($3,800) in Salzburg to £4,559 ($6,850) in Tokyo. Private jet travel is a growing, multi-trillion dollar global industry mostly for the wealthy, with 2.5 million flights in the US in 2013 and 705,000 in Europe. The busiest and most expensive travel times coincide with major events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix. Surprising airports like Bristol (UK), Darwin (Australia), Toronto (Canada), Dublin (Ireland), and Salzburg (Austria) also rank among the top 10 for highest private jet landing fees.

Katie Gallegos from Clackamas County, Oregon, who runs a dog resort, took her Labrador Cooper and his friend Daisy to a McDonald's drive-thru for ice cream. While Daisy eats slowly, Cooper quickly eats the entire cone in one bite, a behavior he is known for. Gallegos ensures Daisy gets her share first and addresses concerns about feeding the dogs treats by noting Cooper is healthy and her previous dog lived a long life with similar treats. The video of Cooper’s ice cream outing has gone viral with over seven million views. In another video, the dogs visit Starbucks for a "pup-uccino" (whipped cream in a cup), with Cooper quickly eating that treat as well. Some viewers find the scenes funny or cute, while others criticize giving dogs such treats, but Gallegos maintains it is safe for her dogs.

Gary Locke, previously interim manager at Kilmarnock, has been appointed the club’s permanent manager after signing a three-year contract. Formerly the assistant to Allan Johnston and ex-Hearts boss, Locke took over when Johnston resigned in February. Since then, he has lost only once in seven games.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp from Eustis, says her five-year-old autistic son Logan was threatened with suspension by Seminole County Elementary School because he wears essential oils to help manage his condition. Teachers claimed the oils, manufactured by doTERRA and applied to his head and neck, distracted other students due to their smell. Kemp maintains that the oils help her son stay calm and focused and has used them all year. After complaints from a teacher's aide, Kemp received a letter from the school board stating the oils caused problems. Despite this, Kemp is determined to continue using the oils, which include scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood. However, the school district later stated Logan would not be suspended, considering the matter a health issue.

A beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton, known as the Sandpiper and open seasonally between May and November, was destroyed by a massive fire on Wednesday afternoon. The blaze, which spread quickly through all 90 condos, generated intense smoke visible three miles away and melted paint off nearby buildings. Twelve fire crews responded but were unable to enter the structure, which eventually collapsed. The cause of the fire is under investigation, with some suggesting it may have started near a parked car. Residents and staff, including building manager Rob Taber who lost all his belongings, were devastated by the destruction.

The 88-year-old Queen continues to enjoy horse riding, recently seen in Windsor Great Park on her black Fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, despite a knee injury limiting her riding in recent years. She prefers wearing silk scarves instead of helmets to preserve her hair. The Queen has loved horses since childhood, received her first pony at age four, and has bred and ridden many horses throughout her life. She currently breeds Fell and Highland ponies, with Fell ponies being an ancient, hardy British breed valued historically for their strength and now popular for riding. Some of her ponies are now ridden by her grandchildren.

A noise dispute between two Brisbane neighbours resulted in the death of 55-year-old Leon Yeaman, allegedly killed by a single punch from 28-year-old Phillip Pama. The altercation began when Yeaman was making loud noise at night, disturbing Pama, who was trying to sleep before a shift. Pama confronted Yeaman and struck him during the confrontation. Yeaman died at the scene, and Pama has been charged with manslaughter but was granted conditional bail. The case will return to court on May 18.

A 52-year-old music teacher, Yulia Simonova, attempted to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old former student, Damian Vanya, after he ended their relationship. Simonova offered 100,000 rubles (£1,400) for the crime and described in detail the violent acts she wanted the hitman to commit. Police set up a sting operation in Shatura, near Moscow, with an undercover officer posing as the hitman, and filmed Simonova ordering the attack. After she handed over expense money, she was arrested and charged with attempted murder, facing up to 15 years in prison. Vanya expressed relief at her arrest and hoped for a lengthy sentence.

Jose Mourinho, Chelsea football manager, said in an interview that he has a strong faith in God and prays daily, but never about football. He separates his professional and family life, never discusses football with his wife, and only prays for personal matters. Mourinho and his family are aware of poverty and have worked as ambassadors for the World Food Programme. He describes himself as a good person despite his intense professional persona and admits to making mistakes in his competitive career. At the time, Chelsea was leading the league, and Mourinho had recently been fined for criticizing football authorities. He attends church regularly only when in Portugal.

Bob Barker returned to host "The Price is Right" on April 1 for the first time in eight years, briefly replacing current host Drew Carey. At 91, Barker hosted the first game before Carey resumed, and he appeared as capable as ever despite his long absence.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in southeast Washington D.C. just after midnight on Friday for allegedly attempting to break into a house and has been charged with attempted burglary and destruction of property. Baldwin, who works in the agency's foreign missions branch, had his security clearance revoked and was put on leave. His arrest follows other recent misconduct cases in the Secret Service, which are being investigated by the Homeland Security inspector general.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life to photograph a hungry male lion at close range in a safari park. Saeed left his car, crept to within 10 feet of the lion, and took several photos before the camera shutter alerted the animal. He had to escape quickly as the lion charged, narrowly making it back to his car. Saeed later reflected on the danger of the encounter and doubted he would attempt it again.

New York City police are seeking the public's help to identify a woman, believed to be 25–45 years old, who was found dead on March 22 in the Gravesend area of Brooklyn. She had no identification but had a distinctive tattoo—a heart with a ribbon, the name "monique," and a rose—on her right leg. Police released images of the tattoo and a tattoo artist's rendering to aid identification. The cause of death is still being determined, and anyone with information is urged to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a solar-powered, two-bedroom home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK and finding they couldn't afford property. Over a year and a half, they constructed the wood and steel house themselves for about $25,000. Now living in Nelson, New Zealand, their home is nearly self-sufficient, with solar panels for power, a wood-fired stove, gas-powered stove and hot water, and water from a spring. Surrounded by nature, they enjoy a cozy, personal space and plan to build another similar home in the future.

Researchers found that kindergarten children who shared iPads in class performed much better in early literacy tests than those who used iPads individually or had no iPad access, scoring about 30 points higher. The study, led by Courtney Blackwell with 352 students, suggests the improved literacy is due to collaborative learning around the technology. The findings indicate schools should reconsider how tablets are used to maximize their effectiveness, particularly in early grades.

A piglet born without back legs has become an internet sensation after mastering how to walk on its front trotters. Featured in a popular online video, the piglet, owned by farmer Ms Duan from Qionglai City, Sichuan, China, is seen wobbling but ultimately balancing and foraging for food with its siblings, all of whom have four legs. The animal, nicknamed 'super pig,' has attracted many visitors and captivated thousands online. Similar praise was previously given to a two-legged rabbit in China that learned to walk on its front paws.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, pit crew member Todd Phillips, a tire changer for Dale Coyne Racing, was injured when he was struck by Francesco Dracone’s car as Dracone spun exiting his pit box on lap 25. Phillips received stitches for a leg cut and was released from the infield care center. Wet conditions from prior rain caused traction issues for many cars. Dracone did not finish the race and placed 23rd.

A husband, Milton Vieira Severiano, brutally murdered his wife, dancer Cicera Alves de Sena (stage name Amanda Bueno), in Rio de Janeiro just four days after they were married. CCTV footage shows Severiano dragging his wife outside, smashing her head into concrete 11 times, punching her 10 times, and then shooting her in the face five times. He confessed to the crime, stating he was jealous of men looking at her. After the murder, Severiano fled in a stolen car and was arrested by police, who found multiple firearms and a bulletproof vest in his vehicle. He now faces life in jail.

Sarah Wilson, journalist and author of "I Quit Sugar," revealed in a candid interview that she has struggled with mental illness, including anxiety and depression, which at times brought her close to suicide. She attributed her struggles to factors such as stress, thyroid disease, and family distance, and described feeling isolated. Wilson now accepts her anxiety and believes depression and anxiety are closely linked, emphasizing the importance of acknowledging this to address rising rates among Australian women. She noted that anxiety is becoming increasingly common, with one in three Australian women experiencing it in their lifetime. Support resources mentioned include Beyond Blue and Lifeline.

An Oregon woman, Elena Curtin, who was seven months pregnant, was charged with second-degree assault after beating her boyfriend’s ex-girlfriend with a crowbar upon finding her using heroin in Curtin’s bathroom in November 2014. Prosecutors have dropped the charges, stating Curtin was "completely justified in her outrage," as Oregon law permits physical force against intruders who refuse to leave. The ex-girlfriend had a history of harassing Curtin, and the boyfriend had a past heroin problem. Curtin has since given birth, ended her relationship, and now lives with her parents. Had she been convicted, Curtin would have faced nearly six years in prison.

Gemma, a pit bull living in California, was filmed rejecting a piece of broccoli disguised among treats, showing disgust and spitting it out. The passage notes hope that the children she lives with do not copy her dislike of vegetables. Other videos show Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her family.

HSBC has apologised after a link on its official website directed users to a pornographic page. The issue occurred because the web address for the Young Entrepreneur Awards, scrapped in 2011, was taken over by a porn site after its registration lapsed. HSBC removed the link once they became aware and stated they have no association with the external website. They apologised for any inconvenience and insisted their website remains secure.

A 13-year-old boy in Maryland called 911 when his family’s home in Clinton caught fire, providing calm instructions to firefighters and comforting his 9-year-old sister while they were trapped in an upstairs bedroom. He reported that his mother, stepfather, and older brother were also in the house. Firefighters rescued the siblings through a window, and both were hospitalized with non-life threatening injuries. The other family members escaped on their own and were also hospitalized. Fire officials praised the boy’s calm and heroic actions during the emergency.

Amazing images have been captured of blue fluorescent algae lighting up Jervis Bay on Australia's east coast. Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the neon glow as a "beautiful supernatural scene," caused by millions of plankton emitting light. This phenomenon, also previously observed in Sydney’s Manly Beach in August 2014, is due to a single-celled phytoplankton called Noctiluca scintillans, which glows as a defense mechanism and typically blooms in spring and autumn for natural reasons. Oceanography expert Iain Suthers emphasized that the occurrence is mostly natural and not a cause for concern.

New genetic tests for breast cancer can determine the aggressiveness of tumors and the likelihood of recurrence, allowing some patients to avoid chemotherapy if their risk is low. These tests, such as Endopredict, analyze cancer cells after surgery and provide results within days, sometimes showing a recurrence risk as low as five percent—similar to or better than the odds with chemotherapy. Although most women currently receive chemotherapy as a precaution, the treatment's severe side effects make alternatives desirable. Experts believe that not all patients need chemotherapy, and using such tests could reduce unnecessary treatment and associated costs. While currently expensive and available mostly privately, specialists hope these tests will become widely accessible through the NHS.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, with incidents on at least 19 ships, including HMS Ocean and HMS Illustrious. Military rules prohibit pregnant women from serving at sea or in war zones, so most cases involve women who conceived before deployment or while on leave. In Afghanistan, 99 pregnant servicewomen were sent home between 2006 and 2013, and 102 from Iraq. These evacuations typically occur on flights for injured personnel, and actual numbers may be higher. Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, making up about 9% of personnel in 2014, and strict "no touching" rules apply at sea.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive cesium was found on the roof of the Japanese prime minister’s residence, raising concerns about the risk of terrorism involving drones. The drone, equipped with a camera, smoke flares, and a bottle of radioactive material, was discovered on the same day a court approved restarting nuclear reactors, a controversial move in Japan. While the small amount of cesium did not pose an immediate health risk, officials expressed concern about potential future terrorist attacks, especially during upcoming major events. Currently, there are no drone flight restrictions over much of Tokyo, including government buildings. Prime Minister Abe was not present at the time.

Lu Xincai, a security guard from Zhejiang province, China, takes his 84-year-old mother, who suffers from Alzheimer’s disease, to work with him every day on the back of his motorbike because he fears she will get lost if left alone. After his father's death and with no one else available to care for her, Lu helps his mother get up at 5 a.m., securely ties her to him for the journey, and rides slowly for an hour to work. His employer provides a room for her at the bank where he works, and he regularly checks on her during the day. Lu is devoted to his mother in gratitude for her care during his childhood, stating that looking after her is his duty.

Between 2005 and 2012, heavy drinking among Americans increased by 17.2%, mainly due to rising rates among women as social norms changed. The study, tracking adult drinking at the county level, found binge drinking among women rose over seven times faster than among men. In 2012, 8% of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers, though the overall percentage of people consuming any alcohol stayed the same. The rise in binge and heavy drinking is attributed to factors including greater social acceptance for women, increased affluence, cheaper alcohol prices, more advertising, and weaker alcohol control policies. Alcohol use is linked to significant health and economic consequences, including nearly 88,600 deaths in 2010 and an annual cost exceeding $220 billion.

UN officials warn that doctors are performing caesarean sections too readily, putting women and babies at risk of infections, complications, and even death. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends caesareans only be done when medically necessary, suggesting an ideal rate of 10-15%, while in England over a quarter of births are now by caesarean, more than double the rate in the early 1990s. The procedure is often done without medical need, sometimes due to women’s anxiety about childbirth, and is significantly more expensive than natural birth. WHO’s position contradicts current NHS guidelines, which allow caesareans on request, and warns that doctors may underestimate the risks, with about one in ten caesareans causing infections.

A 44-year-old woman, Michelle Filkins of West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 after allegedly breaking into a home in Martha’s Vineyard, living there for at least a week, and selling stolen items from the property in a yard sale. She was charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property after the homeowner, Mark Conklin, found her in his summer home, which is valued at $800,000. Filkins initially claimed she owned the house and fled when confronted. Police later arrested her when she tried to re-enter the home. Stolen items included furniture, a grill, lamps, and a painting. Police have asked anyone who bought or received these items to return them and assured buyers they will be treated as victims and assisted in seeking restitution. Filkins is scheduled to appear in court on May 14.

A woman named Bella Crooke lost her iPhone at a friend's birthday party in Melbourne. The phone was handed in to the Albury police station on the NSW-Victoria border. Officers found the phone unlocked and posted humorous selfies and photos on Bella’s Facebook page to help track her down, using puns about phones and jails. The posts gained attention from her friends. When Bella arrived to collect her phone, police recognized her from her Facebook profile and returned the device without needing her name. Bella appreciated the police’s humorous approach and has since put a password on her phone.

A five-day-old baby hippo was killed after being caught in a violent fight between two adult male hippos at the iSimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa. The calf was thrown into the air and dragged across the water while its mother watched in horror, unable to save it. Tour operator Stacey Farrell witnessed the incident, explaining that the mother tried unsuccessfully to protect her calf. The baby hippo died from its injuries a few hours after the attack.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, one of Britain’s most expensive areas, is for sale at £575,000—much cheaper than comparable properties—because it has only three years left on its lease and needs renovation. The annual cost equates to £191,000 per year (or £15,000/month), matching typical local rental rates. If the lease is extended, the flat could be worth over £6 million, but extending the lease for 90 years is estimated to cost £3.35-£4.5 million. A second, larger maisonette nearby is also for sale for £595,000 with just three years on the lease. Both properties are attracting significant interest due to their rarity, but experts warn that the low price comes with the high cost of necessary lease extensions.

Starbucks experienced a computer outage on Friday that affected registers at 8,000 stores in the US and Canada, preventing staff from accepting credit cards and prompting baristas to give away free drinks and food. The outage began in the early evening and was caused by a failure during a daily system refresh. Many stores closed early to avoid giving away more free products.
